Anki/Getting-Started.title: Getting Started
Anki/Getting-Started.content:
How to Use Anki: An Efficient Tutorial for Beginners
We‚Äôre going to cover ONLY the most essential elements of Anki that you should focus on, so you can:

Immediately start using this awesome spaced repetition software
Avoid the same mistakes that I did; and
Have a roadmap that tells you what‚Äôs actually important when using Anki

Capabilities of Anki
If you don‚Äôt know already, here are a couple of things Anki allows you to do in a nutshell:

Schedule reviews automatically, so you don‚Äôt have to worry about which specific topic to study
Study 1714.29% more efficiently as compared to those using conventional flashcards
Study only what needs studying
Encode information into long term memory at will, rather than by chance
Remember almost anything you want without having to re-read
Study anywhere! Studying felt less effortful than ever the moment I started using Anki before. What a blessing.

Now, this guide exists because I believe you just need to learn the few core info if you‚Äôre just looking to start.
It‚Äôs much like learning how to drive a car:

You don‚Äôt start driving a car by studying the ENTIRE manual. You only need to get better at using the ESSENTIAL controls to be able to start driving it.

Real Talk: What is Anki? How does it work?
As you may know, Anki is an open-source flashcard app that uses spaced repetition algorithms to help you prevent natural forgetting.
Even if you‚Äôre not born with awesome recall skills, Anki can help you to¬†intentionally commit information into long-term memory.
But there‚Äôs a caveat.
That is, Anki works by supplementing your study process.
As good as it is, it‚Äôs NOT a magic pill nor a substitute for poor learning skills.
Why? Because Anki covers just the final one-third of the memory‚Äôs core processes for information encoding. ‚Äî which is retrieval.
This means that if the first two-thirds of the system you use for studying ‚Äî encoding & storage ‚Äî is messed up, then using Anki won‚Äôt be the magic pill that it‚Äôs believed to be.
In contrast, when you do use Anki with the right process, you could gain tremendous advantage over the competition:

You basically guarantee that anything you study (again, using the right process) WILL get remembered for a long time.
You build up a tall stack of prior knowledge that allows you to understand complex concepts quickly.
You eliminate the most time-wasting study activity of all ‚Äî ‚Äúrestudying what you‚Äôve already studied because you forgot‚Äù
You can turn downtime into productive study time (when you use Anki while eating, for example, it allows you to practice 50 items in a breeze)

Best of all, you get a tremendous long-term efficiency benefit:
Michael Nielsen mentioned that in 20 years, he is 1714.29% (120 minutes/7 minutes * 100%) more efficient for each card when learning using spaced repetition compared to conventional flashcard learning.
Sound good so far? I‚Äôm hearing questions‚Ä¶
‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt Anki just good for memorizing small facts?‚Äù
Contrary to popular belief, just because Anki is a flashcard app doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs only used for memorizing words or raw facts.
As I imply in the last section, Anki is also a tool for LEARNING ‚Äî which means it helps you establish a ‚Äúlibrary of mental models‚Äù for understanding higher-level concepts.
I never skip Anki because in my mind, if I don‚Äôt retain all the prerequisite knowledge I‚Äôm required to remember, then it‚Äôd be hard for me to understand higher-level concepts in the future. (Ultimately, this causes even more wasted time.)
‚ÄúIf Anki is so effective, then why do so many people fail at using it?‚Äù
Why do SO MANY people go into flashcard hell?
Glad you asked. A few reasons why:

They use shared decks (most of which are ineffective). They keep trying to remember what they haven‚Äôt even learned yet. Learn before you memorize!
They have an unwieldy deck structure. Don‚Äôt create artificial knowledge barriers! As a rule of thumb, you should have one deck for each retrieval context. (exam, interview, language, field, etc.) NOT a deck for every section or topic of a book!
Intermittent Reviews. They do Anki reviews intermittently‚Äîas if natural forgetting can be ‚Äúskipped.‚Äù
Their thinking is stuck in Anki and ignore the other 2/3 of the learning process. They functionally fix themselves into Anki ‚Äî they see it as ‚Äúthe entire system‚Äù when really, it‚Äôs really just ‚Äúa small part of the engine‚Äù. Learning skills matter.

Note: I‚Äôm well aware that you can use shared decks effectively for standardized exams, but I really don‚Äôt recommend it ‚Äî UNLESS you‚Äôre in Medical School. I know of people who‚Äôve created and used high-quality shared decks with great success, and you can find them here.
Thing is, most of these people who fail at using Anki treat is as a magic pill, instead of a tool that requires skill. (Woah, that rhymed‚Ä¶)
As Michael Nielsen put it in his essay:

Anki is an extremely simple program [‚Ä¶] Despite that simplicity, it‚Äôs an incredibly powerful tool. And, like many tools, it requires skill to use well. It‚Äôs worth thinking of Anki as a skill that can be developed to virtuoso levels, and attempting to continue to level up toward such virtuosity.

Creating your first Anki cards
To create cards, just hit the ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù on the top part of your window.

By clicking on it, you should be seeing the Add New window containing (1) Type, (2) Deck, (3) Front and Back fields, and (4) Tag field.

Now, I wouldn‚Äôt worry about the ‚ÄúFields‚Ä¶‚Äù and ‚ÄúCards‚Ä¶‚Äù buttons just yet. They‚Äôre just card customizations that don‚Äôt make any difference at all to your recall.
Like I said at the beginning of this guide, this is supposed to be about the essentials ‚Äî and they‚Äôre just ain‚Äôt it.
So don‚Äôt even think that you need them.
Trust me, you‚Äôll get VERY FAR without even touching those things.
Now, in the ‚ÄúAdd New‚Äù window, the question goes in ‚ÄúFront‚Äù and the answer goes in ‚ÄúBack‚Äù field, just like your good ol‚Äô paper flashcards.

Once you‚Äôve entered your desired Question and Answer pair, you can click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù or just use the shortcut ‚ÄúCtrl + Enter‚Äù or ‚ÄúCmd + Enter‚Äù to make the card.

Note: Make sure to DOUBLE CHECK the ‚ÄúDeck‚Äù field before adding the card to prevent future headaches.
By the way, the card you‚Äôve just seen is one of the ‚ÄúBasic‚Äù Card Types.

Yes, there are a few card types ‚Äî but remember that the principle here is still to help yourself review information through recall.
The ‚ÄúBasic‚Äù card type allows you to perform the traditional flashcard studying ‚Äî Question in front, Answer at the back.
The Cloze deletion, on the other hand, is a ‚Äúfill-in-the-blank‚Äù type of card.
The others are self-explanatory based on their name.
Question, foreseen: Which Anki card types are the best for learning?
YES. The answer is yes‚Ä¶but I‚Äôll explain.
The best card type is the one that has the best fit for the information you have learned.
And guess what? The most flexible way to do that (without sacrificing the quality of learning) is by making Q&A cards with a Basic card type.
I‚Äôm speaking from experience, too: Cloze and reversed cards are hard to pull off unless you know how to create quality cards.
So my advice to you is to practice creating questions and answers first using a Basic card type. Only create Cloze cards for things that cannot be answered through recognition memory.
In short, start with only using Basic cards. Worry about the others once you can already make that work for you.

Organizing your cards
Like I said earlier, I like to use Tags instead of subdecks.
Why tags? Because it simplifies everything. You need not worry about creating subdecks for each subject because you can use ‚ÄúCustom Study‚Äù more selectively later on.
You can add Tags to your cards in two ways:

During Card Creation, or
Using the Card Browser

I recommend adding Tags during Card Creation ‚Äî it‚Äôs much faster and more proactive.
To add Tags during card creation, you just enter the name of your desired Tag on the ‚ÄúTags‚Äù field of the Add New window.

Here‚Äôs something to remember: Replace spaces with underscores.
Note: If you missed that and accidentally entered two words separated by spaces, you‚Äôll be creating TWO tags for your cards, not one.
Now, creating that card, you should notice that the Tag name you entered in the Tags field did not go away.
This means you can create and create several cards without having to worry about putting Tags in every single time‚Äîthat‚Äôs pretty handy.
The second method of adding tags is via the Card Browser. You open it up by clicking on ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù on the Home Screen or pressing ‚ÄúB‚Äù in the same place.

Here‚Äôs how:

Click on a deck where you can find the to-be-tagged cards
Select your cards on the right-hand side (you can select multiple)
Right-click, then go to Notes > Add Tags

)
I don‚Äôt prefer this method because it‚Äôs rather easy to mess this up.
Imagine accidentally adding tags to other cards when you already have a large collection of cards ‚Äî just thinking about organizing it is already a disaster.
But, you do what you wanna do üôÇ
Here‚Äôs How I Make Anki Flashcards
When you‚Äôre creating your cards, IMO the best way to create high-quality cards is to have these elements in place:

A specific question
A specific answer
Screenshot of source
Tags (optional)

You should be good as long as you have those.
To demonstrate, I‚Äôll be using a random book from the medical field (a field I don‚Äôt know anything about) just to demonstrate this process from a beginner standpoint.
So, when I see something on my book like this:

This card below is the one I make. I included the Question, Answer, Screenshot, and Tag.

PRO TIP: You can add new lines to the ‚ÄúBack‚Äù field if you want to add more details such as mnemonics or screenshots.
Notice that I italicized and bolded the word ‚Äúpreviously‚Äù to show emphasis. It‚Äôs a way to make a cue for an answer more salient and easier to process.
Let‚Äôs look at the card preview.

Looks awesome!
By the way, I want to tell you that for dense conceptual subjects, I break each concept down into more questions that test my understanding.
And this requires that I understand the thing FIRST.
This is the iron rule of effective card-making‚Ä¶
Learn first before you memorize! (Rules #1 and #2 in the classic Twenty Rules of Formulating Knowledge)
Facts are good to include as cards, for sure. But you have to encourage your understanding of the material ‚Äî otherwise you‚Äôll end up doing rote memorization. You‚Äôll end up with a LOT of knowledge that you cannot even use.
A pro tip from me:
You can also simulate situations that use the concept itself so you don‚Äôt miss out on actually applying what you have learned.
See this card, for example:
)
See how that works?
Alright, let‚Äôs move on to what you need to remember when creating new cards.
Tips for Creating Good Anki Flashcards
1 ‚Äì Learn FIRST, and THEN create flashcards from what you‚Äôve learned
Just like what I said a while ago, you gotta learn first before you make your cards.
If you‚Äôre just starting out, all you need to know is that the purpose of these flashcards is to test what you already learned.
Folks, it‚Äôs ‚Äúremember what you learn‚Äú, and not ‚Äúlearn what you remember‚Äú.
It‚Äôs easy to get confident that you can remember anything using Anki, but the truth is that NONE of that matters if you do not understand the material you‚Äôre putting in.
(Unless you‚Äôre really memorizing isolated facts, but even so, context matters for retention)
Well, what‚Äôs the worst that could happen when you don‚Äôt follow this rule?
You‚Äôll know how to answer the flashcard but you‚Äôll find out that you cannot apply the ‚Äúknowledge‚Äù anywhere else.
In other words, you just get pseudoknowledge.
2 ‚Äì One simple card is worth 2x the vague cards
Don‚Äôt try to put in paragraphs in a card.
Don‚Äôt even try to put ‚ÄúExplain‚Äù type of questions.
Break them down until it‚Äôs simple FOR YOU.
This brings me to my next point.
3 ‚Äì The number of cards don‚Äôt matter much; coverage matters more
There‚Äôs no optimal number of cards.
Think about what‚Äôs important here: It‚Äôs important that you have made cards that can cover the entire material you‚Äôve understood.
So when adding cards, it doesn‚Äôt matter if you have plenty of cards just by studying a chapter as long as you follow the two rules above.
What matters is you actually learn the concepts thoroughly.
Break a concept as much as possible.
By doing these two things, you‚Äôll feel like you‚Äôre able to recall each card in less than a second. (Well, not physically less than a second, but that‚Äôs how it‚Äôll feel like üòâ)
It‚Äôs much, much faster compared to creating a few but long, complicated cards.
For example, instead of:
‚ÄúWhat are Newton‚Äôs Three Laws of Motion?‚Äù
You write questions like:

‚ÄúWhat is Newton‚Äôs First Law of Motion?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat is Newton‚Äôs Third Law of Motion?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhich law states F=ma?‚Äù (obviously, this question covers one law in another angle ‚Äî also called redundancy)

This reduces ambiguity ‚Äî making your cards faster to answer. Compare that to doing a mini-brain dump for each card and you‚Äôll realize it gets tiresome pretty quickly.
Just to be clear, there‚Äôs no stopping you from creating both types of cards.
Feel free to experiment, because there really are times when a longer card can be more efficient. Let‚Äôs avoid black-and-white thinking here.
Still not sure how to properly structure your flashcards?
Well, in that case, I made a quick reference of examples just for you.
This quick reference will show you 13 flashcard examples and anti-examples so you can get started making good flashcards and avoid creating bad ones.
Specifically, you‚Äôre going to discover some of the¬†most important lessons¬†I‚Äôve gained¬†from¬†manually¬†creating 4000+ flashcards:

You can click the red button below to go to the signup page.
How to use Anki for studying anywhere (without feeling like you‚Äôre studying)
Head over to Anki Sign Up and register for an account. It‚Äôs totally free. That‚Äôs why Damien Elmes is a hero.
Then, after creating an account, press ‚ÄòSync‚Äô on your Anki‚Äôs home screen.

A dialog box requiring your details will pop up.
Simply enter the details you signed up for at AnkiWeb, and this will allow automatic syncing of your deck to the AnkiWeb servers‚Äîwhich allows you to sync your cards to ALL devices.
It‚Äôs pretty neat, especially if you‚Äôre going outside with your smartphone. (or when you‚Äôre sitting on the toilet ‚Äî not exactly neat, tho)
When you‚Äôre waiting in line, or just doing nothing at all, instead of scrolling through Facebook, you can answer 5 to 20 cards in a minute, depending on how good you create cards.
That means you‚Äôre converting idle time into STUDYING.
If that isn‚Äôt called studying smart, I don‚Äôt know what is.
You can turn it off and manually sync your cards by pressing Y on the home screen, but it‚Äôs always a good idea to sync your cards automatically upon open/exit just to avoid forgetting.
Smash That Spacebar!
Studying using Anki is pretty straightforward.
You just open the app, click a deck with due cards, and you‚Äôre set.
When a card shows up, you just press on the spacebar to show the answer.

When the answer shows up, you are given choices below to choose from: Again, Good, Easy.
Using Anki default settings, Anki will show the card again after a certain amount depending on how difficult it was for you to recall the card.

Again ‚Äì Less than a minute, the card will show up again
Good ‚Äì The card will show up in less than 10 minutes
Easy ‚Äì The card will show up after 4 days

My method is simple:

You press Again when you failed to recall the answer,
You press Good when you successfully recall the answer
You press Easy when you meet two things: you already know the answer a long time ago, and you have recalled the answer in an instant

You can use Answer Button shortcuts as shown below:

As a side note for default settings, pressing ‚ÄúAgain‚Äù on a mature card for a total of 8 times makes your card ‚Äúdisappear‚Äù and not show up for review.
This is called a ==Leech card==, and is usually classified as a poorly created card.
When you get Leech cards, all you have to do is reformulate your questions. Again, refer back to how I told you to create flashcards.
Alright, now before I end this, I would like to give you some tips that would help you study smarter using Anki.
Why You Should NEVER Miss a Day of Review
Forgetting happens every single day. This means that poorly learned, seldomly used information are good as DELETED every single day.
Anki works to combat this effect. (But again, follow my tip#1 when creating cards)
Another reason not to skip is you end up with a mountain of cards the next day. Yup, now you‚Äôll have to review your overdue cards PLUS your due cards ‚Äî that‚Äôs a hell of a review session to go through (trust me, I‚Äôve been through 1500 cards in a day and I almost cried just doing that).
So, try do study every single day without fail.
Closing Thoughts: Anki is a great tool for studying ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not the entire study system
As powerful as Anki is, it‚Äôs just a tool that depends on your skills ‚Äî and I want to make sure I drive that point home.
There‚Äôs always a sense of ‚Äúwonder‚Äù in exploring new tools especially when it promises to solve our problems with having the lack of time.
But my advice, from experience, is to look at efficiency a different way:
Instead of adding tools, think about eliminating wastes.
That‚Äôs the purpose of tools in the first place ‚Äî to help us eliminate effort that isn‚Äôt adding any value or not leading us closer to our goal.
Anki eliminates the non-value-adding activity called ‚Äúscheduling your reviews and worrying about whether you need to review each item today or not.‚Äù (Yeah, that‚Äôs a mouthful)
But do NOT, by any means, expect that it‚Äôs a magic pill that will make you remember anything without skill and work ethic.
What‚Äôs Next?

Download AnkiCollab addon üåê AnkiCollab
Sign up account on AnkiCollab and subscriber to your deck:
Setup Subscriber to Your Personalized Deck

Anki/Setup-Subscriber.title: Setup Subscriber
Anki/Setup-Subscriber.content:
Getting Started - Subscriber
The subscription key üîë is all you need!
The key will be a series of words separated by dashes. Example:
pip-item-hawaii-skylark-network-rugby





















StudentSubscription KeyThanhecho-triple-fifteen-jig-jupiter-winneTLinhgee-floor-fifteen-jig-jupiter-winnerTrungitem-victor-fifteen-jig-jupiter-winner
Video Guide
If you prefer to watch a video, here is the latest guide:

Adding the Key to Anki


Open Anki.


On the toolbar, click AnkiCollab ‚Üí Edit Subscriptions.

This window will show all your current subscriptions.

Add a new deck by pasting it into the box at the bottom and clicking Add Subscription.

There will be a confirmation and you can now close this window.
The deck may not show up immediately! If you don‚Äôt see the deck, click the Deck button at the top of the main Anki page to refresh üîÑ the view.

If you see the title of the deck pop up, you are ready to start reviewing! üëç


Suggesting Changes
Card Content and Tags
Not every Anki deck is perfect ‚Äî typos, content errors, strange formatting, or other issues might pop up. There might even be some errors in this very document that will get changed in the future!
One huge strength of AnkiCollab is the ability to let the maintainer know that there might be an issue with a deck.
‚ö† In this section, we‚Äôll be showing how to change a card‚Äôs content within the fields, but the process is identical for tags.
Let‚Äôs say you subscribe to a deck and find this card:

Sure, elephants üêò are big, but you know that the biggest animal in the world is actually a Blue Whale üê≥.
After double-checking that you‚Äôre correct, change the word Elephant to Blue Whale in the same manner you would edit a normal card.
Once you‚Äôve edited the card, click the AnkiCollab button.

A small window will pop up and ask you to choose a rationale for making this change.

In our case, let‚Äôs choose Content Error. Next, click OK.
You‚Äôve now submitted your first change!
From the maintainer‚Äôs point of view, they‚Äôll see a window like this:

This page tells the maintainer what exactly was changed and why.
From here, they can approve or reject your suggestion. If approved, everyone who subscribed to this deck will receive an update with your change.
You are now ready to go into the AnkiCollab world and improve decks! üëç
New Cards
Some decks on AnkiCollab are unfinished, looking for people to contribute and finish them. In this case, you don‚Äôt want to be editing cards, but adding new ones.
‚ö†Ô∏è Before you start adding cards, make sure you are adding them to the correct deck!
Let‚Äôs say you subscribed to a Flower Identification deck, but they‚Äôre missing the California Poppy. When adding the card, all you have to do is check the Suggest on AnkiCollab button toward the bottom.

Now you just need to wait for the maintainer to approve your card!
Downloading Updates
To download any changes or new content for your subscribed deck, you can manually check for new content or automatically check for updates on startup.
Check for New Content Manually
On the toolbar, click AnkiCollab ‚Üí Check for New Content.

This will retrieve any available updates for your subscription.
If any updates are available, you will be shown the changelog and asked if you want to Install Now, Skip this Update, or Decide Later.

Check for New Content Automatically
On the toolbar, click AnkiCollab ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Check for Updates on Startup.

When you startup Anki, AnkiCollab will automatically check for updates and prompt you to install any available updates.

Transcript


                  
                  Part 4 
                  
                


Specifically, | am referring to Stoicism, which, in my opinion, is the most practical of all philosophies and therefore the most appealing. Stoicism was founded in Ancient Greece by Zeno of Citium in the early 3rd century BC, but was practised by the likes of Epictetus, Cato,
Seneca and Marcus Aurelius. Amazingly, we still have access to these ideas, despite the fact that the most famous Stoics never wrote anything down for publication. Cato definitely didn‚Äôt. Marcus Aurelius never intended his Meditations to be anything but personal.
The road to virtue, in turn, lay in understanding that destructive emotions, like anger and jealousy, are under our conscious control ‚Äî they don‚Äôt have to control us, because we can learn to control them. In the words of Epictetus: ‚Äúexternal events | cannot control. but the choices | make with regard to them Ido control‚Äù.
The modern day philosopher and writer Nassim Nicholas Taleb defines a Stoic as someone who has a different perspective on experiences which most of us would see as wholly negative;
The founding fathers of the United States were inspired by the philosophy. George Washington was introduced to Stoicism by his neighbours at age seventeen, and later, put on a play based on the life of Cato to inspire his men. Thomas Jefferson kept a copy of Seneca beside his bed.
The economist Adam Smith‚Äôs theories on capitalism were significantly influenced by the Stoicism that he studied as a schoolboy, under a teacher who had translated Marcus Aurelius‚Äô works.
Stoicism had a profound influence on Albert Ellis, who invented Cognitive Behaviour Therapy, which is used to help people manage their problems by changing the way that they think and behave. It‚Äôs most commonly used to treat depression. The idea is that we can take control of our lives by challenging the irrational beliefs that create our faulty thinking, symptoms and behaviours by using logic instead.
Stoicism has also become popular in the world of business. Stoic principles can build the resilience and state of mind required to overcome setbacks because Stoics teach turning obstacles into opportunity. A lesson every business entrepreneur needs to learn.
| would argue that studying Stoicism is as relevant today as it was 2,000 years ago, thanks to its brilliant insights into how to lead a good life. At the very root of the thinking, there is a very simple way of living ‚Äî control what you can and accept what you can‚Äôt. This is not as easy as it sounds and will require considerable practice ‚Äî it can take a lifetime to master. The Stoics also believed the most important foundation for a good and happy life is not money, fame, power or pleasure, but having a disciplined and principled character ‚Äî something which seems to resonate with many people today.

Daily Wrap Up
Vocabulary


revs one‚Äôs up: make sb or sth become more active

Example: ‚ÄúNothing revs me up, oh baby like you do.‚Äù



a cheap shot (n): a criticism or attack on someone that‚Äôs unfair.

Example: ‚ÄúMaking fun of his parents was a cheap shot. Shame on you‚Äù



purgatory (a) an extremely unpleasant experience that causes suffering.


pejorative (a): expressing disapproval, or suggesting that something is not good or is of no importance.


atrophy (n): to be reduced in size and therefore strength, or, more generally, to become weaker.

Example: ‚ÄúDepending on AI-generated code can hinder self-growth, deprive learning opportunities and lead to skill atrophy.‚Äù



a blip?: a snap out of existence

‚ÄúHe blipped so technically he‚Äôs not allowed to drink.‚Äù

experience¬†with.

Introduction.title: Introduction
Introduction.content:
Greetings, Family
Our class will begin this week, I hope that we will have a smooth sailing journey together.
A Personal Note
First, this is deeply personal for me, and I trusted you guys to keep this between us, so DO NOT share with anyone, okay? Even though it‚Äôs on public domain :D
Typically, I would jot down these reflections in my journal but for this occasion, to motivate you guys, to hopefully ignite a flame of undying passion for learning, I would like to share a snapshot of my life. First, one of my early mottos:

My thirst for knowledge will never be quenched.
If you don‚Äôt like it, then tough luck, take this as a reading task, and I‚Äôve highlighted the vocabulary that you‚Äôve learned, not the new ones.
So, to mark the commencement of our learning endeavor, here are your first tasks:




                  
                  This week's tasks 
                  
                


  First-level of recursion for new words on this reading task.
 Your comments/remarks (at least 3), send me personally or via group chat, suit you.
 Extra 2 points for those who note grammar structures used as well. An exhaustive one.



‚ö†Ô∏èNote  Minus 1 point for each vocabulary word you miss if asked. Missing means that you haven‚Äôt noted it yet.
Autobiography
People often tell me how ‚Äúa normal person‚Äù would behave differently than I do, so I guess it‚Äôs only reasonable that my school life wasn‚Äôt typical either, lol.
Compared to my peers, I didn‚Äôt study as much, playing most of the time and often doing the bare minimum or finding unconventional shortcuts to keep pace with them. But lucky me, the so-called ‚Äúpeers‚Äù were all geniuses, so I got put in place a lot. Even if I fooled around, the baseline level of effort to keep up helped me pass almost every important test entry.
My life has been the complete opposite and will probably become of this quote:

You either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain.


Without any intervention, wandering with perplexity and curiosity, I turned into a bad, but meticulous kid that no one seemed to notice.


I believe the duality of one‚Äôs nature will always be present, but my poor decisions were taken lightly, or more accurately, went by unawares.
I‚Äôm not proud, but thankfully, I could get back on the right track without much of a fight.

Primary School
This period was what I called ‚ÄúA Dark Era,‚Äù a time filled with confusion and all sorts of emotions with no self-awareness and restraint.

I was a perfect role model student and, better yet, a bully.
Too sharp for my own good, excelling at anything I picked up, so naturally, I got things in my favor.
People‚Äôs attention and praise probably took a heavy toll on me, feeding an ego that I didn‚Äôt know how to process, but that was no excuse. I was led astray, blinded by the rewards and recognition.

Maybe subtle blame for uncontrollable primal instincts‚Äîaggression, violence, and the desperate need for validation.üòå
Let‚Äôs not delve further‚Ä¶
Secondary School
The Muted Aftermath
A got-away-with-it-somehow spoiled brat ended up in the top class of the top secondary school. I came to my senses only much later on, back then I was still feigning ignorance and acting on impulse, as most children would.
Therefore, I got this uncalled-for luxury of going to school by taxi‚Äîyep, a taxi, alongside my neighborhood friends. Truly a story to be bragging about, for bourgeois families.
The academic life went south from here üòÖ as the impetuous desires got the better of me. I skipped classes more than I skipped meals.
I would told the cab driver to stop by the net on the way to school =))) and he would happily do so, since he was paid. Not my kid, not my problem üòÇüòÇ Gotta respect that attitude. Had a lot of fun and a lot of bad grades‚Ä¶ Everything was on a downward spiral, yet funny enough, I never got caught or confronted.
Underappreciated Youth
I formed bonds with most of my closest friends here with the most unfiltered, raw, and rough version of myself. The same goes for them.
These low-maintenance relationships, I believe, will stay unstained, growing stronger yet unaffected by time and distance as it has always been.
We were not only in the best but also the wealthiest class. We could go on weekend trips if any of the generous parents were happy that their kid scored a 10. A local prize would almost guarantee a trip and a national one!? We‚Äôd have back-to-back class holidays! Without spending a dime.
This seemingly chill class turned out to have the highest unprecedented acceptance rate at Lam Son Gifted High School.
I doubt I‚Äôll ever have as many extravagant field trips as I did back then. I got to see so much of Vietnam‚Äôs beauty and historical richness ‚Äî things I had long taken for granted.
But it wasn‚Äôt just the scenes and places I overlooked; it was the people too. I discovered so many new emotions‚Äîones that were pivotal, inevitable, but bitterish‚Äîregret, sorrow, rage, and that heartbroken feeling, or whatever you‚Äôd name it.
Most of these feelings were directed at myself: for the decisions I left unmade, for the precious people I failed to cherish until they quietly walked out of my life forever.
Though painful, these realizations became the compass points guiding my future path and were the turning point for me.
High School
Getting into Lam Son has been my most significant cornerstone, though I didn‚Äôt realize it only until recently.
It wasn‚Äôt the school‚Äôs prestige or education (which, in and of itself, is remarkable) that made the difference‚Äîit was the people here who changed me for the better, forever.
My typical day here would start like this:

I‚Äôd wake up late and rush to school, couldn‚Äôt make it on time, thinking ‚Äúscrew it,‚Äù and go buy breakfast with extra, extra toppings, leisurely enjoying every bite.
I was the class secretary, so it was easy for me to make up a lot of excuses for my 15-to-30-minute tardiness. I did this so frequently that everyone gradually stopped questioning my legitimacy.
Getting away with it almost every time - the pinnacle of gaslighting, huh?

The daily inquiries were rather simple:

What should I eat next?
Where should we hang out after school?
Should we play Werewolves, Ribbit, or Exploding Kittens today?
What rhetorical questions should I ask to make it more impactful during the debate?
Would the Literature teacher let us play board games instead? I probably shouldn‚Äôt be the one bringing it up since she wasn‚Äôt particularly fond of me.
We were in the middle of the game so it would suck if the flow is broken like this.
A board game session typically lasts around 2 hours, but some teachers were flexible enough to let us play through. That‚Äôs why I had the Audacity to consider asking in the first place, though not all were as accommodating.

A Regime That Should Have Been Universal
The educational autonomy level I got was unprecedentedly and inimitably high, along with a hefty budget for students.
We had the freedom to decide how to spend our time, with a monthly salary exceeding a million ‚Äîa huge amount back then,  far more than one student could reasonably spend‚Äî for basically existing.
Students who lived a bit off the beaten track would earn almost twice as much.
Big monetary rewards were given (around 9.000.000‚Ç´ per semester per student) for getting an 8.5 GPA, which was not hard, at all.
The school‚Äôs monthly budget for us was roughly 2 billion VND, as stated by the headmaster.
Amidst all this, the school policy was:

If you wanted to play, play. If you wanted to learn, learn.

By all means, that was the best thing since sliced bread for me.
I got the habit of playing truant since the regulations are so flexible and open. You got to decide what‚Äôs next for you; the temptation level is obviously off the chart for a student, you see.
I could attend only half the lessons (usually two) in the morning, go to the net to play video games, skip the afternoon lecture, and go to the coffee shop with my friends, who would skip as well.
When I first got admitted, I did this a lot, with leading repercussions, of course‚Ä¶ Still, I am lucky enough to have many friends of the same frequency who would do those silly stuff with me and make so much memories, yet I could recount them like the back of my hand.
Each class is financially independent, covering its own bills for electricity, water, and cleaning.
We had a 65‚Äô touchscreen TV, 2 pairs of JBL Speakers in the name of learning listening üòÇ, and lots of mics üé§üé§üé§.
We even bought a pine tree and snow-dry ice dispenser for Christmas.
Every day was either karaoke or movie day with mixed board games and debate contests (a type of roleplay with two opposing teams in parliamentary style, regarding local issues to international dilemmas).
Karaoke was almost an indispensable daily activity, or at least I made it so.
We all shared the same music taste and could jam to the beat forever, do headbang, and even pull off dance covers. The stage was almost always overcrowded.
Despite all the temptations that might have been, the biggest one was not coming to class and missing out on something. I stopped playing truant, more or less.
We traveled a lot, even by plane once, to various provinces in Vietnam. We even got to spend 4 days in Da Nang during the fireworks season; that‚Äôs when I won my 3rd girlfriend, a.k.a current bff, over as well, making it kinda memorable for me. Needless to say, looking back, everything is full of laughter, thrills, and endless singing üéµ üé∂üéµ.
That‚Äôs probably why I love karaoke; it feels like stepping into a bittersweet simulation. Though it‚Äôs never quite the same, the experience always brings back those core memories subconsciously in the best way.
Nostalgia hits hard ü•∫üò¢
Bittersweet Epiphany
From what I can recall, everyone was innocent and carefree in a sense, embracing every passing moment without the slightest care in the world.
The inquiry of what would become of us, or what our hopes and dreams for the future were, never crossed our daily train of thought. Yet I‚Äôm certain they will become the brightest people I know; some already are and are on the brink of refining their identities.
I can still remember that feeling, vaguely - the way dreaming came as naturally as breathing. Just now, I remember someone from those days gave us a name: üå±L√°mer.
For me, high school was when the seed of my fantasies and aspirations was planted, and the mold of my true self was finalized, all stemming from those naive and untroubled experiences. None of what I have achieved, or will achieve, could have happened without those everlasting moments when we could afford to be dreamers. Those fleeting, precious  days shaped our dreams and life trajectories, allowing us to envision a future filled with endless possibilities.
Why do I tell you all this? Why not?
I realized some time ago that the privileges I received should not be taken for granted, as I wouldn‚Äôt trade them for anything.
Now, I see them as something I have to bear on my shoulders, my responsibilities. The spark of life üåüI received is something I long to share, driven by both my sense of obligation and wholeheartedness.
Passing The Torch üî•üî•üî•
Back in the days, my mother brought up the idea that I should take on teaching as a profession. I used to despise that so much, claiming I hated teaching without any real reason‚ÄîI still don‚Äôt know why I said that.
Ironically enough, I started tutoring in 12th grade, have had more than 100 students, and now you guys are my next endeavors.
With hindsight, my mom was quite a prophet, nh·ªâ?
I often tell students about my teachers,  who put me on the right track even when I had strayed far from it‚Äîwhich fact never mattered to them.
I owe a great deal to my life sabers for guiding me during times I needed it most, even without realizing it at the time.
I realized that many kids would have been a lot better off had they met the teachers I once had, those who have the most unconventional methods that I can somewhat fathom now.
My very first students were forced upon me as favors asked by relatives, leaving me with little room for decline. Slowly but surely, teaching had crept up on me and intrigued me as I saw the growth and influence it can have on both parties.
Even though I‚Äôm still learning, I feel like I‚Äôve got a lot to share.

Sharing Is Caring.

Knowledge isn‚Äôt meant to be hoarded like treasure ‚Äî it‚Äôs meant to flow freely, like water. I‚Äôve been fortunate enough to stumble upon this cheat code, and it would be selfish to keep it to myself.
Cheat Code For Life
I believe I possess a wide spectrum of emotions and strong knowledge utilization and I attribute this sort of accomplishment largely to learning languages.
Out of all the skills I‚Äôve learned, learning English has been my ultimate cheat code. I see it as a bridge that connects me to anywhere, any souls across cultures.
I still remember the first time I heard lyrics in a language not my mother tongue, yet they resonated deeply. I had butterflies in my stomach, a sadness so profound that it wrenched my heart. That feeling when words echo straight to the heart, not the brain ‚Äî I felt like discovering an entirely new part of myself.
Then, the new refreshing experiences kept flowing: breaking down in tears watching movies, giggling at random jokes in the comments, discovering beauty hidden between the lines, having words spiraling out of your mind that you didn‚Äôt know were in your possession, and finally seeing the payoff of your efforts.
From the moment I can proudly claim English as my second language, I felt like I got a master key that unlock virtually every door. I‚Äôve walked in the shoes of people from different corners of the world, sharing nothing but a common language, yet it was enough to foster both sympathy and empathy.
Each conversation, each perspective shared, reshapes my understanding of the world. With the advent of the Internet, it‚Äôs like having multiple lives in parallel: experiencing countless joys, struggles, triumphs, and so many unnamed emotions through the eyes of people I‚Äôve never met. Truly a cheat code.
While this might seem commonplace to some, we fell into the category of those who weren‚Äôt entitled to it.
It upsets and frustrates me to see so many may forever remain ignorant of the potential of their growth had they known a few more things.
The foreign viewpoint that reduces a language to merely a subject exists only because they haven‚Äôt witnessed its miracles ‚Äî how it can transform your outlook overnight.
What they dismiss as ‚Äújust English‚Äù is actually a portal to infinite glitches: to friendships that span continents, to knowledge that hasn‚Äôt been translated or better yet translated into this most accessible language, to perspectives that challenge everything you know, to opportunities that others can‚Äôt ever fathom.
They haven‚Äôt yet realized that a language isn‚Äôt just a tool for communication‚Äîit‚Äôs a lens through which to view the world, a key to unlock different versions of yourself simultaneously, to experience the cultural and personality subtle shift as you switch language, and ultimately to a more prosperous eye-opening life.
If you have faith in yourself and trust in me:

Those desired objectives will become your realities.

What‚Äôs Next?
Now, you have familiarized yourself with your teacher. Let‚Äôs move on to the class guidelines.

Weekly Routine

Lecture-Notes/2nd.content:
Grammar
Sentence Structure
To-be Sentences (Descriptive)
Personal Descriptions:

‚ÄúThe weather is beautiful today‚Äù
‚ÄúThis coffee is too hot‚Äù
‚ÄúThe students are very attentive‚Äù

‚ÄúI am excited about the trip‚Äù

‚ÄúThe chef prepares amazing dishes‚Äù
‚ÄúStudents submit assignments online‚Äù
Impact on Others:
‚ÄúYour story inspires many people‚Äù
‚ÄúThis music calms my nerves‚Äù

Tenses Review

Here‚Äôs a detailed elaboration with contextual examples:
Present Tense
1. Schedules & Routines
Daily Life:

‚ÄúThe bus arrives at 7:30 AM every morning‚Äù
‚ÄúMy first class starts at 9:00 AM‚Äù
‚ÄúThe cafeteria closes at 8 PM‚Äù

2. Universal Facts & Scientific Truths

‚ÄúThe Earth revolves around the Sun‚Äù
‚ÄúWater freezes at 0 degrees Celsius‚Äù
‚ÄúPlants need sunlight to grow‚Äù

3. Personalities & Characteristics

‚ÄúShe speaks four languages fluently‚Äù
‚ÄúHe excels at problem-solving‚Äù

Habits

‚ÄúThey always arrive early to meetings‚Äù
‚ÄúShe drinks green tea every morning‚Äù

Present Continuous
1. Current Actions (Right Now)

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs preparing dinner right now‚Äù
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre discussing the new project‚Äù

2. Ongoing Temporary Situations
Job Search

‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking for a new apartment‚Äù
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre renovating our house‚Äù

Studies

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs studying for her final exams‚Äù
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre working on their thesis‚Äù

3. Complaints & Annoyances
Family Life

‚ÄúThe neighbors are always playing loud music‚Äù
‚ÄúThe kids are constantly fighting‚Äù

Work Situations

‚ÄúMy colleague is always coming late‚Äù
‚ÄúThe printer is forever breaking down‚Äù

4. Near Future Plans
Travel:

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre flying to Paris next week‚Äù
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre moving to Singapore next month‚Äù

Social Plans:

‚ÄúI‚Äôm meeting Sarah for coffee tomorrow‚Äù
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre having dinner with the Johnsons tonight‚Äù

Present Perfect: Connecting Past to Present
1. Life Experiences
Travel:

‚ÄúI have visited five countries this year‚Äù
‚ÄúShe has never been to Europe‚Äù

Achievements:

‚ÄúHe has won three competitions since January‚Äù
‚ÄúThey have published ten papers in their career‚Äù

2. Recent Actions with Current Impact
Work:

‚ÄúI have just finished the report‚Äù
‚ÄúWe have already sent the email to the client‚Äù

Study:

‚ÄúI have completed all my assignments‚Äù
‚ÄúShe has studied for six hours today‚Äù

3. Ongoing Situations
Life Changes:

‚ÄúI have lived in Tokyo for five years‚Äù (still living there)
‚ÄúThey have worked together since 2018‚Äù (still working)

Relationships:

‚ÄúWe have known each other since college‚Äù
‚ÄúShe has been married for ten years‚Äù

Pronunciation
Vietnamese Vs English Pronunciation: Key Differences
1. Jaw Movement Differences
Vietnamese Characteristic:

Minimal jaw movement (mostly lips and tongue)
Shorter mouth opening
More contained sounds

English Requirement:

Exaggerated jaw movement needed
Wider mouth opening for clear vowels
Practice exercises:

‚ÄúBATH - BAT - BED - BAD‚Äù
‚ÄúSHEEP vs SHIP‚Äù
‚ÄúFOOL vs FULL‚Äù



2. Breath Control & Diaphragm Usage

Vietnamese Speaking:

Chest-level breathing
Shorter breath units


English Speaking:

Deep diaphragmatic breathing required (L·∫•y h∆°i t·ª´ b·ª•ng)
Longer breath units for stress patterns



3. Vowel Combinations
Vietnamese Challenge:

Tendency to separate vowels
Adding glottal stops between vowels

English Requirement:

Smooth transitions needed
Common combinations to practice:

‚Äúia‚Äù as in ‚Äúmaterial‚Äù /m…ôÀàt…™ri…ôl/
‚Äúui‚Äù as in ‚Äúfluid‚Äù /ÀàfluÀê…™d/
‚Äúoa‚Äù as in ‚Äúboat‚Äù /b…ô ät/

Lecture-Notes/7th.title: 7th
Lecture-Notes/7th.content:
Meets the eye
Active Listening Skills

Stay engaged: maintain eye contact, nod, show understanding
Avoid distractions: put phone away, clear desk
Take strategic notes while listening

Note-taking Techniques


Quick Abbreviations

w/ = with
w/o = without
b/c = because
& = and
nums = numbers
‚Üí = leads to/results in
‚Üë = increase/up
‚Üì = decrease/down



Map Exercise Strategy

Listen for direction words first (north, south, left, right)
Note landmarks with simple symbols (üè†, üè´, üå≥)
Draw rough sketch while listening
Confirm route by retracing steps



Names & Numbers

Split numbers in chunks (075-331-4422)
Use phonetic alphabet for spelling names
Echo back for confirmation



Second Brain Method


Digital Note Organization

Use folders by topic/subject
Tag important information
Link related concepts
Regular review and update



Capture Methods

Quick notes during listening
Voice recordings
Mind maps for complex topics
Review within 24 hours

active listening
mnemonics
short-term memory

resort to (v)
self-awareness
mnemonics

Materials/Quizzes/present-tense-quiz.title: Present Tense Review Quiz
Materials/Quizzes/present-tense-quiz.content:
Present Tense Review Quiz
Quiz Settings

Time Limit: 45 minutes
Points: 100
Attempts Allowed: 2

Questions
Question 1
Type: multiple_choice
Points: 20
Question: Choose the correct form of the verb for the sentence: ‚ÄúMy brother _____ basketball every weekend.‚Äù

 play
 plays
 playing
 are playing

Question 2
Type: text_entry
Points: 30
Question: Complete this sentence using the present continuous tense: ‚ÄúRight now, I _____‚Äù (use the verb ‚Äúlearn‚Äù)
Answer: Right now, I am learning English.
Question 3
Type: matching
Points: 25
Question: Match the subjects with their correct present simple verb forms:

The cat | sleeps
I | sleep
You | sleep
They | sleep
She | sleeps

Question 4
Type: essay
Points: 25
Question: Write a paragraph describing your typical morning routine using present simple tense.
Instructions:

Use at least 5 different verbs
Include time expressions (e.g., always, usually, sometimes)
Write 4-5 sentences
Pay attention to third-person singular (he/she/it) verb forms

Canvas Sync Status

Last Sync: pending
Status: pending

quizpresent-tenseassessmentttl-class

Vocabulary/A-Pinch-Of-Salt.title: A Pinch Of Salt
Vocabulary/A-Pinch-Of-Salt.content:
a pinch of salt
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to not completely believe something that you are told, because you think it is unlikely to be true:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


You have to take everything she says with a pinch of salt, because she tends to exaggerate.

Vocabulary/A-Pinch-Grain-Of-Salt.title: A Pinch-Grain Of Salt
Vocabulary/A-Pinch-Grain-Of-Salt.content:
a pinch/grain of salt
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to not completely believe something that you are told, because you think it is unlikely to be true:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/A-Sense-Of-Something-(respons.title: A Sense Of Something (responsibility-burden-sorrow-etc.)
Vocabulary/A-Sense-Of-Something-(respons.content:
a sense of something (responsibility/burden/sorrow/etc.)
Word Type: Phrase
Definition
A feeling, awareness, or understanding about something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe had a sense of pride after completing the difficult project.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe book conveys a sense of mystery and intrigue.‚Äù
‚ÄúWalking into the old house gave him a sense of nostalgia.‚Äù
‚ÄúThere was a sense of relief when the test results came back positive.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team worked together with a sense of purpose to achieve their goal.‚Äù

Vocabulary/A-The-Bare-Minimum.title: A-The Bare Minimum
Vocabulary/A-The-Bare-Minimum.content:
a/the bare minimum
Word Type: Phrase
Definition
the smallest amount or least effort required to achieve something, just enough to meet a basic need or standard.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHe did the bare minimum to pass the class, turning in only the required assignments.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe only brought the bare minimum for the trip, just a few clothes and toiletries.‚Äù
‚ÄúTo finish the project on time, we need the bare minimum of resources.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe company is offering the bare minimum benefits required by law.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe job was simple, so all he had to do was the bare minimum to complete it.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Ability.title: Ability
Vocabulary/Ability.content:
ability
Definition
Word Type: noun
the physical or mental power or skill needed to do something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


There‚Äôs no doubting her ability.

Vocabulary/Ably.title: Ably
Vocabulary/Ably.content:
ably
Word Type: adverb
Definition
skilfully:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He performs his duties very ably.

Vocabulary/Accommodating.title: Accommodating
Vocabulary/Accommodating.content:
accommodating
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Willing to help or make things easier for others; flexible and obliging.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe was very accommodating when I needed help with my project.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe hotel staff was accommodating, offering us an early check-in.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe was always accommodating to his friends, making sure everyone was comfortable.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe manager was accommodating enough to reschedule our meeting.‚Äù
‚ÄúTheir accommodating attitude made the difficult situation much easier to handle.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Accomplishment.title: Accomplishment
Vocabulary/Accomplishment.content:
accomplishment
Word Type: Noun
Definition
Something achieved successfully, especially through effort, skill, or perseverance.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúGraduating with honors was a proud accomplishment for her family.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis greatest accomplishment was building a successful business from scratch.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe artist‚Äôs latest exhibit is considered a major accomplishment in her career.‚Äù
‚ÄúCompleting the marathon was an incredible accomplishment, given the tough conditions.‚Äù
‚ÄúLearning to cook gourmet meals was a personal accomplishment she cherished.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Aggravate.title: Aggravate
Vocabulary/Aggravate.content:
aggravate
Definition
Word Type: verb
to make a bad situation worse:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Attempts to restrict parking in the city centre have further aggravated the problem of traffic congestion.

Vocabulary/Aggression.title: Aggression
Vocabulary/Aggression.content:
aggression
Word Type: Noun
Definition
Aggression refers to hostile or violent behavior or attitudes toward another person or group.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHis aggression during the debate made everyone uncomfortable.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe country‚Äôs aggression led to widespread fear in the region.‚Äù
‚ÄúSports often bring out both the competitive spirit and occasional aggression in players.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe aggression shown by the protesters was met with a strong police response.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe had to manage his aggression in order to work effectively in a team.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Agnostic.title: Agnostic
Vocabulary/Agnostic.content:
agnostic
Definition
Word Type: noun
someone who does not know, or believes that it is impossible to know, if a god exists:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Although he was raised a Catholic, he was an agnostic for most of his adult life.

Vocabulary/Ambiguously.title: Ambiguously
Vocabulary/Ambiguously.content:
ambiguously
Word Type: adverb
Definition
in a way that has or expresses more than one meaning:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Some questions were badly or ambiguously worded.

Vocabulary/Amidst.title: Amidst
Vocabulary/Amidst.content:
Amidst(Amid)
Word Type: Preposition
Definition
In the middle of or surrounded by something, especially when referring to a situation or environment.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe remained calm amidst the chaos of the crowded airport.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team worked hard amidst difficult circumstances to finish the project.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe town has prospered amidst economic challenges.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe found peace amidst the noise of the busy city.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe cat slept peacefully amidst the piles of books on the table.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Analogy.title: Analogy
Vocabulary/Analogy.content:
analogy
Definition
Word Type: noun
a comparison between things that have similar features, often used to help explain a principle or idea:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He drew an analogy between the brain and a vast computer.

Vocabulary/Annoy.title: Annoy
Vocabulary/Annoy.content:
annoy
Word Type: verb
Definition
to make someone angry:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Tina really annoyed me in the meeting this morning.

Vocabulary/Annoyance.title: Annoyance
Vocabulary/Annoyance.content:
annoyance
Definition
Word Type: noun
the feeling or state of being annoyed:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I can understand your annoyance - I‚Äôd be furious if she ever treated me like that.

Vocabulary/Appreciate.title: Appreciate
Vocabulary/Appreciate.content:
appreciate
Definition
Word Type: verb
to recognize how good someone or something is and to value them or it:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


There‚Äôs no point buying him expensive wines - he doesn‚Äôt appreciate them.

Vocabulary/Appreciative.title: Appreciative
Vocabulary/Appreciative.content:
appreciative
Definition
Word Type: adjective
showing that you understand how good something is, or are grateful for something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


appreciative of I‚Äôm very appreciative of all the support you‚Äôve given me.

Vocabulary/As-Naturally-As-Breathing.title: As Naturally As Breathing
Vocabulary/As-Naturally-As-Breathing.content:
As Naturally as Breathing
Definition
Word Type: Idiom
To do something instinctively or effortlessly, without the need for conscious thought or effort, similar to how breathing is an automatic and essential function of life.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


For her, playing the piano came as naturally as breathing; she could effortlessly express her emotions through music.

Vocabulary/Aspiration.title: Aspiration
Vocabulary/Aspiration.content:
aspiration
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A strong desire to achieve something, typically something important or meaningful.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHer aspiration is to become a doctor and help people in underserved communities.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe has high aspirations to start his own business one day.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team‚Äôs aspiration is to win the national championship this year.‚Äù
‚ÄúTheir aspiration for a better future drives them to work hard every day.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe shared her aspiration of traveling the world and experiencing different cultures.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Astray.title: Astray
Vocabulary/Astray.content:
astray
Word Type: Adverb
Definition
To be away from the correct path or direction, or to be led into error or wrongdoing.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe hikers went astray and got lost in the forest.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe was led astray by bad advice from a friend.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe car broke down and we went astray, ending up on the wrong road.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis thoughts were astray, distracted by worries about the future.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe plan went astray when we failed to anticipate the storm.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Attempt-To.title: Attempt To
Vocabulary/Attempt-To.content:
attempt to
Definition
Word Type: verb
to try to do something, especially something difficult:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + to infinitive ] He attempted to escape through a window.

Vocabulary/Attend.title: Attend
Vocabulary/Attend.content:
attend
Word Type: Verb
Definition

To be present at an event, meeting, or place.
To look after or care for someone or something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúI plan to attend the conference next week.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe will attend the meeting to discuss the new project.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe nurse will attend to the patients during the night shift.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe decided to attend the wedding even though he wasn‚Äôt invited.‚Äù
‚ÄúThey attended the seminar on digital marketing to improve their skills.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Attitude.title: Attitude
Vocabulary/Attitude.content:
attitude
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A settled way of thinking or feeling about something, typically reflected in a person‚Äôs behavior.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe has a positive attitude towards her work, always eager to learn.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis attitude toward the project was negative, which affected the team‚Äôs morale.‚Äù
‚ÄúA good attitude can make a difficult job seem easier.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe manager‚Äôs attitude was key in motivating the entire team.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer calm attitude in stressful situations impressed everyone.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Audacity.title: Audacity
Vocabulary/Audacity.content:
audacity
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The willingness to take bold risks or have the nerve to do something, often in a way that is disrespectful or rude.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHe had the audacity to challenge his boss in front of everyone.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe showed great audacity by starting her own business with very little capital.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt takes real audacity to speak your mind in such a large crowd.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe thief had the audacity to rob the store in broad daylight.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis audacity in asking for a raise after only a month on the job surprised everyone.‚Äù



Synonym
temerity

Vocabulary/Autobiography.title: Autobiography
Vocabulary/Autobiography.content:
Autobiography
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A book or piece of writing about a person‚Äôs own life, written by that person.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHer autobiography details her journey from poverty to becoming a successful entrepreneur.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe spent years writing his autobiography, recounting his adventures around the world.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe actor‚Äôs autobiography became a bestseller shortly after its release.‚Äù
‚ÄúIn her autobiography, she shared personal stories about her family and career.‚Äù
‚ÄúReading an autobiography can offer a unique perspective on historical events.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Autonomy.title: Autonomy
Vocabulary/Autonomy.content:
autonomy
Word Type: Noun
Definition
the right of an organization, country, or region to be independent and govern itself:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúGaining financial autonomy was a key goal for her after graduating college.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe region is seeking greater autonomy from the central government.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe values his autonomy and prefers to work without supervision.‚Äù
‚ÄúTeaching children autonomy helps them become more confident and self-reliant.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe organization operates with full autonomy, free from outside interference.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Averse.title: Averse
Vocabulary/Averse.content:
averse
Definition
Word Type: adjective
strongly disliking or opposed to:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Few people are averse to the idea of a free holiday.

Vocabulary/Aversive.title: Aversive
Vocabulary/Aversive.content:
aversive
Definition
Word Type: adjective
making someone feel a strong dislike for something, or making them not want to do it:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


emotionally aversive images

Vocabulary/Awareness.title: Awareness
Vocabulary/Awareness.content:
awareness
Definition
Word Type: noun
knowledge that something exists, or understanding of a situation or subject at the present time based on information or experience:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Public awareness of the problem will make politicians take it seriously.

Vocabulary/Back-In-The-Day.title: Back In The Day
Vocabulary/Back-In-The-Day.content:
back in the day
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
Used to refer to a time in the past, often nostalgically, when things were different or better.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúPeople didn‚Äôt rely on smartphones back in the day.‚Äù
‚ÄúBack in the day, kids used to play outside instead of staying indoors with video games.‚Äù
‚ÄúGas was much cheaper back in the day.‚Äù
‚ÄúBack in the day, we had to write letters instead of sending emails.‚Äù
‚ÄúLife was simpler back in the day, or so it seemed.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Back-To-Back.title: Back To Back
Vocabulary/Back-To-Back.content:
back to back
Word Type: Phrase
Definition
Happening one after another, with no interruption or a very short pause between events.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe team won back to back championships for two years in a row.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe had back to back meetings all afternoon, with no time to take a break.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe worked back to back shifts for a whole week to finish the project.‚Äù
‚ÄúThey had back to back performances at the festival, performing each night.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe concert featured back to back hits from the band‚Äôs latest album.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Bare.title: Bare
Vocabulary/Bare.content:
bare
Word Type: adjective
Definition
without any clothes or not covered by anything:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Don‚Äôt walk around outside in your bare feet.

Vocabulary/Barely.title: Barely
Vocabulary/Barely.content:
barely
Word Type: adverb
Definition
by the smallest amount:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They have barely enough (= no more than what is needed) to pay the rent this month.

Vocabulary/Baseline.title: Baseline
Vocabulary/Baseline.content:
baseline
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A starting point or reference used for comparison or measurement.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe team‚Äôs performance was measured against the baseline set at the beginning of the season.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe need to establish a baseline for the project before making any changes.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe company‚Äôs baseline sales figures are used to predict future growth.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe baseline data will help us track the progress of the new initiative.‚Äù
‚ÄúResearchers used a baseline survey to understand the initial attitudes of the participants.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Be-In-Someone's-Shoes.title: Be In Someone's Shoes
Vocabulary/Be-In-Someone's-Shoes.content:
be in someone‚Äôs shoes
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To be in a situation where you understand or experience the thoughts, feelings, or circumstances of another person.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine what it‚Äôs like to be in her shoes after losing her job.‚Äù
‚ÄúIf I were in his shoes, I would have made a different decision.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy to judge others, but try to be in their shoes before you criticize.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe showed empathy and understood what it would be like to be in his shoes during the tough times.‚Äù
‚ÄúBefore you make assumptions, think about what it would be like to be in someone else‚Äôs shoes.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Be-On-Cloud-Nine.title: Be On Cloud Nine
Vocabulary/Be-On-Cloud-Nine.content:
be on cloud nine
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to be extremely happy and excited:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Be-Over-The-Moon-be-On-Cloud-.title: Be Over The Moon-be On Cloud Nine.
Vocabulary/Be-Over-The-Moon-be-On-Cloud-.content:
be over the moon/be on cloud nine.
Definition
Word Type:
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Be-Over-The-Moon.title: Be Over The Moon
Vocabulary/Be-Over-The-Moon.content:
be over the moon
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to be very pleased:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She was over the moon about/with her new bike.

Vocabulary/Be-Smooth-Sailing.title: Be Smooth Sailing
Vocabulary/Be-Smooth-Sailing.content:
be smooth sailing
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
to be¬†easy¬†and without¬†problems.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúOnce we fixed the engine, the rest of the road trip was smooth sailing.‚Äù
‚ÄúAfter I studied hard for weeks, passing the exam was smooth sailing.‚Äù
‚ÄúStarting the new project was tough, but now everything seems to be smooth sailing.‚Äù
‚ÄúOnce you understand the basics, learning the rest of the language will be smooth sailing.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe negotiations were difficult at first, but after reaching an agreement, it was smooth sailing from there.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Be-Uncalled-For.title: Be Uncalled For
Vocabulary/Be-Uncalled-For.content:
be uncalled for
Word Type: phrase
Definition
To be inappropriate, unnecessary, or unjustified; to lack reason or justification.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


His remarks during the meeting were completely uncalled for and offended many of his colleagues.

Vocabulary/Be.title: Be
Vocabulary/Be.content:
be
Word Type: verb
Definition
used to say something about a person, thing, or state, to show a permanent or temporary quality, state, job, etc.:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


He is rich.

Vocabulary/Bear-Sth-In-Mind.title: Bear Sth In Mind
Vocabulary/Bear-Sth-In-Mind.content:
bear sth in mind
Definition
Word Type: phrase
to remember a piece of information when you are making a decision or thinking about a matter:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Bearing in mind how young she is, I thought she did really well.

Vocabulary/Bear.title: Bear
Vocabulary/Bear.content:
bear
Word Type: Verb
Definition

To carry or support the weight of something.
To endure or tolerate something.
To give birth to (young).



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHe had to bear the heavy load up the mountain.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe managed to bear the pain and complete the race.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe had to bear the harsh criticism from her colleagues.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe mother lion bore three cubs during the winter.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe couldn‚Äôt bear the thought of leaving her hometown.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Bearable.title: Bearable
Vocabulary/Bearable.content:
bearable
Definition
Word Type: adjective
If an unpleasant situation is bearable, you can accept or deal with it:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


As far as she was concerned, only the weekends made life bearable.

Vocabulary/Become-Of-Someone-something.title: Become Of Someone-something
Vocabulary/Become-Of-Someone-something.content:
become of someone/something
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To happen to someone or something, especially what happens to them in the future.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúWhatever became of that old car you used to drive?‚Äù
‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know what became of her after she moved to the city.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe company has grown so much, I wonder what became of the small startup it once was.‚Äù
‚ÄúNo one knows what became of the missing documents.‚Äù
‚ÄúI wonder what became of the books we donated to the library years ago.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Become-Of-Us.title: Become Of Us
Vocabulary/Become-Of-Us.content:
become of us
Definition
Word Type: phrase
refers to what will happen to a group of people (including the speaker) in the future, often expressing concern or uncertainty.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


She wondered what would become of them after they graduated.

Vocabulary/Behave.title: Behave
Vocabulary/Behave.content:
behave
Word Type: Verb
Definition

To act in a particular way, especially in a way that is socially acceptable or appropriate.
To conduct oneself in a proper or expected manner.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe children were told to behave during the ceremony.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe always behaves politely in front of guests.‚Äù
‚ÄúIf you behave well, you‚Äôll get a treat.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt know how to behave in such a formal setting.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe dog needs to be trained to behave around strangers.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Better-Off.title: Better Off
Vocabulary/Better-Off.content:
better off
Word Type: Adjective, Noun and Idiom
Definition

to have more money than you had in the past or more money than most other people:
to be in a better situation, if or after something happens:
To be in a better or more favorable situation, typically after a change or decision.(idiom)



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúObviously we‚Äôre better off now that we‚Äôre both working.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe‚Äôd be better off working for a bigger company.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou would be better off taking the bus instead of driving during rush hour.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe would be better off working from home rather than commuting every day.‚Äù
‚ÄúAfter the breakup, he felt better off focusing on himself for a while.‚Äù

Noun: ‚ÄúThe echo of her voice filled the empty hall.‚Äù
Verb: ‚ÄúHis words echoed through the canyon.‚Äù
Verb: ‚ÄúHer feelings of excitement echoed in the crowd‚Äôs cheers.‚Äù
Noun: ‚ÄúWe could hear the echo of the church bells from miles away.‚Äù
Verb: ‚ÄúThe speech echoed the sentiments of unity and strength.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Narcissism.title: Narcissism

Vocabulary/Off-The-Chart.content:

Vocabulary/Off-The-Charts.title: Off The Charts
Vocabulary/Off-The-Charts.content:
off the charts

Word Type: idiom
at a very high level.

Vocabulary/On-End.content:
on end

continuously:

Vocabulary/On-Impulse.title: On Impulse
Vocabulary/On-Impulse.content:
on (an) impulse
Definition
phrase
because you suddenly want to, although you haven‚Äôt planned to.

Vocabulary/On-The-Brink-Of.content:

Vocabulary/On-The-Right-Track.content:

not certain:

Vocabulary/Outrun.title: Outrun

Vocabulary/Overbearing.content:

Vocabulary/Overbearingly.content:

Vocabulary/Overlook.title: Overlook
Vocabulary/Overlook.content:
overlook

Vocabulary/Overrun.title: Overrun
Vocabulary/Overrun.content:
overrun
Definition
Word Type: verb

Vocabulary/Oversee.title: Oversee
Vocabulary/Oversee.content:
oversee

To make or be similar or equivalent to something.

‚ÄúThe two roads run parallel to each other.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe challenges he faced in life had many parallels with his father‚Äôs struggles.‚Äù

an evergreen tree (= one that never loses its leaves) that grows in cooler areas of the world:
To feel deep sorrow or longing, often for something that is lost or unattainable.

‚ÄúShe has been pining for her hometown since she moved away.‚Äù

ponder

Vocabulary/Ponderable.content:
ponderable

Vocabulary/Ponderous.title: Ponderous
Vocabulary/Ponderous.content:
ponderous

poorness
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Possess.title: Possess

possess

Vocabulary/Praise.title: Praise
Vocabulary/Praise.content:
praise

The expression of approval or admiration for someone or something.
To express approval or admiration for someone or something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe teacher gave her a lot of praise for completing the project ahead of schedule.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe was praised for his hard work and dedication during the meeting.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to praise children for their efforts, not just their results.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Precedent.title: Precedent

precedent

precious

Vocabulary/Preposition.title: Preposition
Vocabulary/Preposition.content:
preposition
Word Type: noun

Vocabulary/Prerequisite.title: Prerequisite
Vocabulary/Prerequisite.content:
prerequisite

Word Type: noun

Vocabulary/Primal-Instincts.content:

‚ÄúDuring the competition, his primal instincts pushed him to run faster than ever.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Proposal.title: Proposal

proposal

Vocabulary/Provided.title: Provided

provided
Definition
Word Type: verb
past simple and past participle of


                  
                  Example

‚ÄúAgainst all odds, the team was able to pull off a victory in the final minutes of the game.‚Äù

‚ÄúDespite the challenges, they pulled off the event without a hitch.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Pulled-It-Off.title: Pulled It Off
Vocabulary/Pulled-It-Off.content:
pulled it off

to succeed in doing something difficult or unexpected:

Vocabulary/Purgatory.title: Purgatory
Vocabulary/Purgatory.content:

‚ÄúThe long, painful recovery after the accident was a form of purgatory for him.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Put-On-A-Face.title: Put On A Face
Vocabulary/Put-On-A-Face.content:
put on a face
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to behave as if a problem is not important or does not worry you:

Vocabulary/Put-On-A-Strike.title: Put On A Strike
Vocabulary/Put-On-A-Strike.content:
put on a strike
Word Type:
Definition
Definition not found


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Put-Sb-On-The-Right-Track.title: Put Sb On The Right Track
Vocabulary/Put-Sb-On-The-Right-Track.content:

Word Type: Verb phrase
Definition

Vocabulary/Put-in-place.title: Put in place
Vocabulary/Put-in-place.content:
put in place
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To establish or implement something, especially a rule, system, or structure.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúNew safety measures were put in place after the accident.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe company has put in place a new policy to improve customer service.‚Äù
‚ÄúA security team was put in place to ensure the event went smoothly.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe government has put in place several programs to address homelessness.‚Äù
‚ÄúAfter the renovation, new guidelines were put in place to maintain the building.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Put.title: Put
Vocabulary/Put.content:
put
Definition
Word Type: verb
to move something or someone into the stated place, position, or direction:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Where have you put the keys?

Vocabulary/Quarrel.title: Quarrel
Vocabulary/Quarrel.content:
quarrel
Definition
Word Type: noun
an angry disagreement between two or more people or groups:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Quench.title: Quench
Vocabulary/Quench.content:
quench
Word Type: Verb
Definition

To satisfy thirst by drinking.
To put out a fire or extinguish.
To stop or reduce something, such as a feeling or desire.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe drank a cold glass of water to quench her thirst after the long hike.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Read-Between-The-Lines.title: Read Between The Lines
Vocabulary/Read-Between-The-Lines.content:
read between the lines
Definition
Word Type: idiom
to try to understand someone‚Äôs real feelings or intentions from what they say or write:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Realization.title: Realization
Vocabulary/Realization.content:
realization
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The act of becoming aware of something or achieving a clear understanding of it; the fulfillment or achievement of something hoped for or desired.

‚ÄúThe realization that she had won the prize took a moment to sink in.‚Äù
‚ÄúAfter hours of study, he had a sudden realization about how to solve the problem.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer realization that she needed to change her career path came after years of dissatisfaction.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe realization of their dream home was something they‚Äôd been working towards for years.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Reasonable.title: Reasonable
Vocabulary/Reasonable.content:
reasonable

‚ÄúThe price for the car seems reasonable, given its age and condition.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe made a reasonable suggestion to improve the project‚Äôs outcome.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe teacher gave a reasonable amount of homework for the weekend.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs reasonable to expect a response within 24 hours.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe restaurant‚Äôs portions were reasonable for the price.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Recognition.title: Recognition
Vocabulary/Recognition.content:
recognition
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The act of acknowledging or identifying someone or something, often with approval or respect.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe received recognition for her outstanding performance in the company.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe artist gained recognition after her work was displayed in a major gallery.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis efforts went unnoticed, but the team later gave him recognition for his hard work.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe award was a well-deserved recognition of his years of dedication.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt seek recognition; he just wanted to help others.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Recount.title: Recount
Vocabulary/Recount.content:
recount
Word Type: Verb, Noun
Definition

To tell someone a story or describe something in detail, especially something that has happened.
A detailed or complete account of an event or experience.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Verb: ‚ÄúShe was asked to recount her experience during the interview.‚Äù
Verb: ‚ÄúHe recounted the events of the trip with great enthusiasm.‚Äù
Noun: ‚ÄúThe book is a recount of the author‚Äôs travels around the world.‚Äù
Noun: ‚ÄúThe recount of the election results showed a close race.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Redeem.title: Redeem
Vocabulary/Redeem.content:
redeem
Definition
Word Type: verb

Vocabulary/Reference.title: Reference
Vocabulary/Reference.content:
reference

Vocabulary/Refine.title: Refine
Vocabulary/Refine.content:

Vocabulary/Reflect.title: Reflect
Vocabulary/Reflect.content:
reflect
Definition
Word Type: verb

                  Example
