Vocabulary/Reflection.title: Reflection
Vocabulary/Reflection.content:
reflection
Word Type: Noun
Definition

The image of something in a mirror, on a shiny surface, or in water.
Serious thought or consideration.
An indication or expression of something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe admired her reflection in the mirror before leaving for the party.‚Äù
‚ÄúAfter the meeting, he spent some time in quiet reflection about the decisions made.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Reflective.title: Reflective
Vocabulary/Reflective.content:
reflective
Word Type: adjective
Definition

Vocabulary/Regime.title: Regime
Vocabulary/Regime.content:

‚ÄúThe country was under a strict military regime after the coup.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe company must comply with government regulations regarding safety standards.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Reinterpret.title: Reinterpret
Vocabulary/Reinterpret.content:
reinterpret

Word Type: verb

Vocabulary/Relive.title: Relive
Vocabulary/Relive.content:
relive

reseal

Vocabulary/Resort-To.title: Resort To
Vocabulary/Resort-To.content:
resort to

to do something that you do not want to do because you cannot find any other way of achieving something:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Retrain.title: Retrain
Vocabulary/Retrain.content:
retrain
Definition
Word Type: verb
to learn new skills so you can do a different job:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Rhetorical-Question.title: Rhetorical Question
Vocabulary/Rhetorical-Question.content:
rhetorical question
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A question asked for effect or to make a point, rather than to receive an answer.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúWhen he asked, ‚ÄòWho doesn‚Äôt want to be successful?‚Äô it was a rhetorical question.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer rhetorical question about the importance of honesty made everyone reflect on their actions.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe teacher used a rhetorical question to emphasize the need for hard work.‚Äù
‚ÄúDuring the speech, the politician asked several rhetorical questions to stir the crowd‚Äôs emotions.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe raised a rhetorical question about the fairness of the decision, leaving no room for debate.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Rhetorical-Questions.title: Rhetorical Questions
Vocabulary/Rhetorical-Questions.content:
rhetorical question
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A question asked for effect or to make a point, rather than to receive an answer.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúWhen he asked, ‚ÄòWho doesn‚Äôt want to be successful?‚Äô it was a rhetorical question.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer rhetorical question about the importance of honesty made everyone reflect on their actions.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe teacher used a rhetorical question to emphasize the need for hard work.‚Äù
‚ÄúDuring the speech, the politician asked several rhetorical questions to stir the crowd‚Äôs emotions.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe raised a rhetorical question about the fairness of the decision, leaving no room for debate.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Rich.title: Rich
Vocabulary/Rich.content:
rich
Definition
Word Type: adjective

                  Example

Vocabulary/Richly.title: Richly
Vocabulary/Richly.content:
richly
Definition
Word Type: adverb

Vocabulary/Richness.title: Richness
Vocabulary/Richness.content:
richness
Definition

the quality of having a lot of something that is valuable or interesting:

Vocabulary/Risk-averse.content:
risk-averse

‚ÄúIn the workshop, participants will role-play different customer service scenarios.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Runic.title: Runic
Vocabulary/Runic.content:
runic

a runic letter/alphabet/message

Vocabulary/Runner.content:
runner

a long-distance runner

Vocabulary/Sanguine.content:
sanguine

Vocabulary/Screw-it.content:

‚ÄúThe weather is bad, but screw it, I‚Äôm going to the beach anyway.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Scribble.title: Scribble
Vocabulary/Scribble.content:
scribble
Word Type: verb
Definition
to write or draw something quickly or carelessly:

Vocabulary/Seal.title: Seal
Vocabulary/Seal.content:
seal

Word Type: noun

Vocabulary/Seance.title: Seance
Vocabulary/Seance.content:
seance
Definition
Word Type: noun
a meeting where people try to talk with dead people:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Secretary.title: Secretary
Vocabulary/Secretary.content:
secretary
Word Type: Noun
Definition

                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe works as a secretary at a law firm, handling all the scheduling and paperwork.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe secretary of the board took detailed notes during the meeting.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe hired a secretary to manage his calendar and correspondence.‚Äù

Vocabulary/See-To-It.title: See To It
Vocabulary/See-To-It.content:
see to it
Definition
Word Type: phrasal verb
to deal with a person or task that needs to be dealt with or is waiting to be dealt with:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/See.title: See

see

Word Type: verb

                  Example

Vocabulary/Seemingly.title: Seemingly
Vocabulary/Seemingly.content:
seemingly

‚ÄúThe solution to the problem seemed seemingly simple, but it took much longer to fix.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe was seemingly happy, but deep down, he was struggling.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team‚Äôs success was seemingly effortless, but they had worked hard behind the scenes.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe gave a seemingly innocent response, but I could tell she was hiding something.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe mountain trail was seemingly easy, but it turned out to be much more difficult than we expected.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Self-Awareness.title: Self-Awareness
Vocabulary/Self-Awareness.content:
self-awareness
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The ability to recognize and understand one‚Äôs own emotions, behaviors, and thoughts, and how they affect others.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúDeveloping self-awareness is key to improving emotional intelligence.‚Äù
‚ÄúThrough meditation, she gained a deeper sense of self-awareness.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Shame.title: Shame
Vocabulary/Shame.content:
shame

show

showy

Vocabulary/Shrink.title: Shrink

shrink

Vocabulary/Shrinkable.title: Shrinkable
Vocabulary/Shrinkable.content:
shrinkable

Definition
Definition not found

shrinkage

Vocabulary/Sight.title: Sight

unable to see

Vocabulary/Simple.title: Simple

sorrow

Vocabulary/Spectacular.title: Spectacular

Adjective: Describing something that has gone off course or is out of place.
Noun: A person or animal that has become lost or separated from a group.



                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Strike.content:

Vocabulary/Stumble-Upon.title: Stumble Upon
Vocabulary/Stumble-Upon.content:
stumble across/on/upon¬†something/someone

‚ÄúI stumbled across an old photo album while cleaning the attic.‚Äù

‚ÄúI stumbled across the book in a library and decided to borrow it.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhile hiking, we stumbled upon a beautiful waterfall.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Subconsciously.title: Subconsciously
Vocabulary/Subconsciously.content:
subconsciously
Word Type: Adverb
Definition

                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe subconsciously avoided the topic because it made her uncomfortable.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Subconsciousness.title: Subconsciousness
Vocabulary/Subconsciousness.content:
subconsciousness
Word Type: noun

Vocabulary/Subtle-Shift.title: Subtle Shift
Vocabulary/Subtle-Shift.content:

Vocabulary/Subtle.title: Subtle
Vocabulary/Subtle.content:
Subtle

Definition

                  Example

‚ÄúShe gave him a subtle hint that she wasn‚Äôt interested in the proposal.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Take-Sb-sth-For-Granted.content:

‚ÄúHer idea for a reusable shopping bag was the best thing since sliced bread in the eco-friendly community.‚Äù

Vocabulary/The-Best-Thing-Since-Slight-B.content:

Vocabulary/The-Duality-Of-One's-Nature.title: The Duality Of One's Nature
Vocabulary/The-Duality-Of-One's-Nature.content:
The Duality of One‚Äôs Nature
Word Type: Phrase/Concept
Definition
The idea that a person or thing has two contrasting or opposing qualities or characteristics, often used to explore the complexity of human behavior or identity.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe novel explores the duality of one‚Äôs nature, showing how the character struggles between good and evil.‚Äù
‚ÄúPhilosophers have long debated the duality of one‚Äôs nature, questioning whether humans are inherently good or bad.‚Äù
‚ÄúIn the film, the main character embodies the duality of one‚Äôs nature, as they shift between being a hero and a villain.‚Äù

Vocabulary/The-More,-The-Merrier.content:

                  Example

Vocabulary/The-Seed-Of.title: The Seed Of

Vocabulary/Tightly.title: Tightly

‚ÄúHe was following a clear train of thought, but a loud noise distracted him.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe detective retraced the train of events leading up to the crime.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Train.title: Train
Vocabulary/Train.content:
train
Definition
Word Type: noun
a railway engine connected to carriages for carrying people or to wheeled containers for carrying goods:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


goods/freight/passenger train The line was closed yesterday after a goods/freight/passenger train derailed.

Vocabulary/Trajectory.title: Trajectory
Vocabulary/Trajectory.content:
trajectory
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The curved path that something follows when it is thrown or propelled through the air, or the general path or progress of something, especially over time.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe rocket‚Äôs trajectory was carefully calculated to ensure it reached orbit.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer career has taken a remarkable trajectory since she started as an intern.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe plane‚Äôs trajectory was altered to avoid a storm.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe company‚Äôs trajectory shows impressive growth over the past five years.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe athlete‚Äôs trajectory in the sport suggests a promising future.‚Äù



Idiom
be on an upward/downward trajectory

Vocabulary/Transitive.title: Transitive
Vocabulary/Transitive.content:
transitive
Definition
Word Type: adjective
(of a verb) having or needing an object:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


In this dictionary, transitive verbs, such as

Vocabulary/Transitively.title: Transitively
Vocabulary/Transitively.content:
transitively
Definition
Word Type: adverb
(of a verb) in a transitive way (= having or needing an object):


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Can

Vocabulary/Transitivity.title: Transitivity
Vocabulary/Transitivity.content:
transitivity
Definition
Word Type: noun
(of a verb) the fact of being transitive (= having or needing an object) or intransitive (= not having or needing an object):


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Transponder.title: Transponder
Vocabulary/Transponder.content:

Definition
Word Type: noun
an electronic device that gives out a radio signal when it receives a similar signal telling it to:

Vocabulary/Turn-Into.title: Turn Into
Vocabulary/Turn-Into.content:
turn into
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To change or transform into something different.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe caterpillar will turn into a butterfly after several weeks.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis hobby eventually turned into a successful business.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat started as a small idea turned into a major project.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe storm quickly turned into a full-blown hurricane.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe argument turned into a full-blown fight by the end.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Turn-Out-To.title: Turn Out To
Vocabulary/Turn-Out-To.content:
turn out to
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To happen in a particular way or to have a particular result, often unexpectedly.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe event turned out to be a huge success.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt turned out that the test was easier than expected.‚Äù
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think they would come, but it turned out that everyone showed up.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe dinner turned out better than I thought it would.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe was worried about the presentation, but it turned out great.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Ubiquitous.title: Ubiquitous
Vocabulary/Ubiquitous.content:
ubiquitous
Definition
Word Type: adjective
seeming to be everywhere:

Vocabulary/Unaffected.title: Unaffected
Vocabulary/Unaffected.content:
unaffected
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Not influenced or changed by something; remaining calm and composed in response to difficult situations or emotions.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúDespite the criticism, she remained unaffected and continued with her work.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis unaffected attitude in the face of adversity made him a strong leader.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe news of the company‚Äôs closure left him unaffected, as he had already planned for such possibilities.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe was unaffected by the noise and focused on her studies.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe serene landscape seemed unaffected by the storm that had passed through.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Unappreciative.title: Unappreciative
Vocabulary/Unappreciative.content:
unappreciative
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not showing that you understand how good something is, or not grateful for something


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Unaware.title: Unaware
Vocabulary/Unaware.content:
unaware
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not understanding or realizing something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + that ] He was unaware that the police were watching him.

Vocabulary/Unawareness.title: Unawareness
Vocabulary/Unawareness.content:
unawareness
Definition
Word Type: noun
the fact of not knowing, understanding, or realizing something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Part of the problem in recent years has been the unawareness of the importance of history among our political leaders.

Vocabulary/Unawares.title: Unawares
Vocabulary/Unawares.content:
unawares
Word Type: Adverb
Definition
In a way that happens unexpectedly or without being noticed.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe loud noise took me unawares as I was focused on my work.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe was caught unawares by the surprise party.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe sudden change in weather took us unawares during our hike.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe was caught unawares when they asked him to lead the meeting.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Unbearable.title: Unbearable
Vocabulary/Unbearable.content:
unbearable
Definition
Word Type: adjective
too painful or unpleasant for you to continue to experience:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


All I remember of my daughter‚Äôs birth was the unbearable pain and the relief when it was all over.

Vocabulary/Uncalled-For.title: Uncalled-For
Vocabulary/Uncalled-For.content:
uncalled-for
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Unnecessary, inappropriate, or rude; not justified or warranted.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHis comments were completely uncalled-for and hurt everyone‚Äôs feelings.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe criticism was uncalled-for, especially since she was just trying to help.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt was uncalled-for to make such a remark at the dinner table.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer outburst was uncalled-for and disrupted the whole meeting.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe joke was uncalled-for and made everyone feel uncomfortable.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Uncomplimentary.title: Uncomplimentary
Vocabulary/Uncomplimentary.content:
uncomplimentary
Definition
Word Type: adjective
rudely criticizing:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Uncontrollable.title: Uncontrollable
Vocabulary/Uncontrollable.content:
uncontrollable
Definition
Word Type: adjective
too strong or violent to be controlled:

Vocabulary/Uncontrollably.title: Uncontrollably
Vocabulary/Uncontrollably.content:
uncontrollably
Definition
Word Type: adverb
in a way that is too strong or violent to be controlled:

Vocabulary/Unconventional.title: Unconventional
Vocabulary/Unconventional.content:
unconventional
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Not following accepted customs or practices; unusual or different from what is typical.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHis unconventional approach to problem-solving helped the company innovate.‚Äù
‚ÄúThey had an unconventional wedding ceremony on a mountaintop.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer unconventional style of dressing made her stand out at the party.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe artist is known for her unconventional use of colors and materials.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Uncreative.title: Uncreative
Vocabulary/Uncreative.content:
uncreative
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not producing or using original or unusual ideas:

Vocabulary/Undying-Passion.content:

                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe pursued her dream of becoming an artist with undying passion.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis undying passion for music kept him performing well into his old age.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe wrote the book fueled by an undying passion for storytelling.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Uneconomical.title: Uneconomical
Vocabulary/Uneconomical.content:
uneconomical

Word Type: adjective
using too much money or too many resources and unlikely to make a profit:

Vocabulary/Ungrateful.title: Ungrateful
Vocabulary/Ungrateful.content:
ungrateful
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not showing or expressing any thanks


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Unimpressive.content:
unimpressive
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not making you feel admiration or respect:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Unjust.title: Unjust
Vocabulary/Unjust.content:
unjust
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not fair:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Unkind.title: Unkind
Vocabulary/Unkind.content:
unkind
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not treating someone very well; not considering someone‚Äôs feelings:

an unkind remark

Vocabulary/Unkindness.title: Unkindness
Vocabulary/Unkindness.content:
unkindness
Definition
Word Type: noun
the quality of not treating someone very well, or not considering someone‚Äôs feelings:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Unlikable.title: Unlikable
Vocabulary/Unlikable.content:
unlikable
Word Type: adj
Definition
mainly US spelling of
unlikeable


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Unmade.title: Unmade
Vocabulary/Unmade.content:
unmade
Word Type: Adjective (also Used as a Verb Form of ‚Äúunmake‚Äù)
Definition

Describes something that is not yet completed or arranged, often referring to something like a bed that has not been tidied or a plan that has been disrupted.
The past participle of ‚Äúunmake,‚Äù meaning to undo or reverse something that was made or created.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe woke up to find her bed still unmade.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe plans for the event were unmade due to unexpected circumstances.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis thoughts were in a mess, leaving his mind feeling unmade and disorganized.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe decision to change the policy was unmade after further discussions.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe room looked unmade, with clothes scattered all over the floor.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Unmake.title: Unmake
Vocabulary/Unmake.content:
unmake
Definition
Word Type: verb
to destroy a reputation or a career:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


Actors‚Äô reputations have been made and unmade on this London stage.

Vocabulary/Unnecessary.title: Unnecessary
Vocabulary/Unnecessary.content:
unnecessary
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not needed or wanted, or more than is needed or wanted:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I thought a lot of the violence in the movie was totally unnecessary.

Vocabulary/Unperceptive.title: Unperceptive
Vocabulary/Unperceptive.content:
unperceptive
Definition
Word Type: adjective
having or showing a lack of understanding because of not noticing things:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


They seem to be woefully unperceptive.

Vocabulary/Unprecedented.title: Unprecedented
Vocabulary/Unprecedented.content:
unprecedented
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Never having happened before; without previous example or parallel.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe pandemic led to unprecedented changes in the global economy.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer unprecedented success in the competition shocked everyone.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe hurricane caused unprecedented damage to the coastal areas.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe country faced unprecedented challenges during the economic crisis.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team achieved unprecedented levels of performance this season.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Unsightly.title: Unsightly
Vocabulary/Unsightly.content:
unsightly
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not attractive; ugly:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Unspectacular.title: Unspectacular
Vocabulary/Unspectacular.content:
unspectacular
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not particularly good or great, and not causing much admiration or excitement:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Unstained.title: Unstained
Vocabulary/Unstained.content:
unstained
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Not marked, damaged, or affected by anything negative; pure or unspoiled.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHer reputation remained unstained despite the controversy.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe fabric was unstained, showing no signs of wear after years of use.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe unstained nature of the landscape made it a perfect spot for a quiet retreat.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe worked hard to keep his record unstained by any mistakes.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe unstained beauty of the forest was a sight to behold.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Untroubled.title: Untroubled
Vocabulary/Untroubled.content:
Untroubled
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Not affected by worries, difficulties, or concerns; calm and peaceful.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe appeared untroubled by the stressful situation, staying calm and collected.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe children played untroubled by the noise around them.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis untroubled demeanor made everyone else feel at ease.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe landscape looked untroubled by the passing storm.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Unwilling.title: Unwilling
Vocabulary/Unwilling.content:
unwilling
Definition
Word Type: adjective
not willing:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


an unwilling helper

Vocabulary/Uptight.title: Uptight
Vocabulary/Uptight.content:
uptight
Definition
Word Type: adjective
worried or nervous and not able to relax:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Utilization.title: Utilization
Vocabulary/Utilization.content:
utilization
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The action of using something effectively for a particular purpose.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe utilization of renewable energy sources is crucial for reducing pollution.‚Äù
‚ÄúEfficient utilization of resources can help a company reduce costs.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe utilization of technology in education has transformed learning methods.‚Äù
‚ÄúProper utilization of time is essential for achieving success.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe utilization of natural habitats by wildlife is closely monitored by conservationists.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Vendor.title: Vendor
Vocabulary/Vendor.content:
vendor
Definition
Word Type: noun
someone who is selling something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


For the past few months she‚Äôs been working as a street vendor, selling fruit and vegetables.

Vocabulary/Via.title: Via
Vocabulary/Via.content:
via
Word Type: Preposition
Definition

Through or by way of a place.
Using a particular method, person, or system to achieve something.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúWe traveled to Italy via France.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe sent me the document via email.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe train to London goes via Manchester.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou can access the website via your smartphone.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe achieved success via hard work and determination.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Villain.title: Villain
Vocabulary/Villain.content:
villain
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A character in a story or situation who opposes the hero, typically being evil or immoral, or a person who engages in wicked or criminal behavior.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe villain in the movie plotted to steal the treasure from the innocent villagers.‚Äù
‚ÄúIn many classic fairy tales, the villain is defeated by the hero in the end.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe was portrayed as the villain of the story, using deceit to get what he wanted.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe villain in the novel was a cunning mastermind who created chaos for everyone.‚Äù
‚ÄúDespite his evil actions, the villain in the story had a tragic backstory.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Violence.title: Violence
Vocabulary/Violence.content:
violence
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The use of physical force intended to hurt, damage, or kill someone or something, or an extreme force or action that causes harm.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe city was shocked by the outbreak of violence during the protest.‚Äù
‚ÄúDomestic violence is a serious issue that needs to be addressed.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe film depicts the consequences of war and the violence it causes.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe authorities are taking steps to reduce violence in the community.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe was a victim of violence on the street late at night.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Virtually.title: Virtually
Vocabulary/Virtually.content:
virtually
Word Type: Adverb
Definition
Almost entirely; very nearly, but not quite.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe project is virtually complete, just a few details left to finish.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe has virtually no experience in the field, yet he got the job.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe two cities are virtually identical in appearance.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe situation was virtually under control after the intervention.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team virtually won the match, with only a small amount of time left.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Walk-In-The-Shoes-Of.title: Walk In The Shoes Of
Vocabulary/Walk-In-The-Shoes-Of.content:
Walk in the Shoes of
Word Type: Idiom
Definition
To understand or experience someone else‚Äôs situation or feelings, often to empathize with them.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúBefore criticizing her decisions, try to walk in the shoes of a single mother.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to truly walk in the shoes of a CEO unless you‚Äôve been one.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe couldn‚Äôt walk in the shoes of someone who had to work two jobs just to make ends meet.‚Äù
‚ÄúTo help others, it‚Äôs important to walk in the shoes of those you are trying to assist.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe movie made me walk in the shoes of a soldier, showing me their daily struggles.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Walk-Out.title: Walk Out
Vocabulary/Walk-Out.content:
walk out
Word Type: Phrasal Verb
Definition
To leave a place suddenly, especially in protest or anger, or to stop participating in something.

‚ÄúShe decided to walk out of the meeting when she disagreed with the decision.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe employees walked out when the company refused to negotiate fair wages.‚Äù
‚ÄúDuring the play, several audience members walked out due to the controversial content.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe was so frustrated that he chose to walk out of the discussion.‚Äù
‚ÄúAfter the argument, she walked out without saying a word.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Wander.title: Wander
Vocabulary/Wander.content:
wander
Word Type: Verb
Definition
To move or travel without a fixed direction or purpose; to roam.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúWe decided to wander through the park and enjoy the scenery.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe tends to wander off when he‚Äôs lost in thought.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe lost dog was found wandering the streets.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe likes to wander around new cities to explore hidden gems.‚Äù
‚ÄúDuring the hike, we wandered off the trail but soon found our way back.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Wealthy.title: Wealthy
Vocabulary/Wealthy.content:
wealthy
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Having a great deal of money, resources, or assets.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHe comes from a wealthy family and has never had to worry about money.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe wealthy businessman donated millions to charity.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe lived in a wealthy neighborhood where most houses had private pools.‚Äù
‚ÄúAfter years of hard work, they became wealthy and traveled the world.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe wealthy investor made significant profits from his real estate holdings.‚Äù

Vocabulary/Willing.title: Willing
Vocabulary/Willing.content:
willing
Definition
Word Type: adjective
to be happy to do something if it is needed:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


If you‚Äôre willing to fly at night, you can get a much cheaper ticket.

Vocabulary/Wonder.title: Wonder
Vocabulary/Wonder.content:
wonder
Definition
Word Type: verb
to ask yourself questions or express a wish to know about something:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


[ + question word ] Shouldn‚Äôt you phone home? Your parents will be wondering where you are.

Vocabulary/Wonderful.title: Wonderful
Vocabulary/Wonderful.content:
wonderful
Definition
Word Type: adjective
extremely good:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Wonderment.title: Wonderment
Vocabulary/Wonderment.content:
wonderment
Definition
Word Type: noun
great and pleasant surprise:


                  
                  Example

Vocabulary/Yawn.title: Yawn
Vocabulary/Yawn.content:
yawn
Definition
Word Type: verb
to open the mouth wide and take a lot of air into the lungs and slowly send it out, usually when tired or bored:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


I can‚Äôt stop yawning - I must be tired.

Vocabulary/aftermath.title: aftermath
Vocabulary/aftermath.content:
aftermath
Word Type: Noun
Definition
the consequences or results of an event, especially a significant or unpleasant one.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe aftermath of the hurricane left the city in ruins.‚Äù

Vocabulary/ambiguous.title: ambiguous
Vocabulary/ambiguous.content:
ambiguous
Definition
Word Type: adjective

                  Example

Vocabulary/as-stated-by.content:

Vocabulary/commencement.title: commencement
Vocabulary/commencement.content:
commencement
Word Type: Noun
Definition
the beginning of something.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe university held its commencement ceremony in the grand hall.‚Äù
‚ÄúTheir wedding day was the commencement of a new chapter in their lives.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe gave a moving speech at his high school commencement.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe commencement of the project was delayed due to unforeseen issues.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe commencement of the new policy sparked a lot of debate.‚Äù

Vocabulary/delve.title: delve
Vocabulary/delve.content:
delve
Word Type: Verb
Definition

to reach into something or under the surface of something trying find an object.
to examine something in detail trying to find information.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe detective decided to delve into the suspect‚Äôs background for more clues.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe spent hours delving into historical archives to find the truth.‚Äù
‚ÄúBefore making a decision, he needed to delve into the data more carefully.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe researcher will delve deeper into the topic during the next phase of the study.‚Äù

Synonym
dig
investigate

Vocabulary/dilemma.title: dilemma
Vocabulary/dilemma.content:
dilemma
Word Type: Noun
Definition
a situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two different things you could do (ti·∫øn tho√°i l∆∞·ª°ng nan).


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe faced a dilemma when offered two job opportunities in different cities.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe company was in a dilemma over whether to raise prices or risk losing customers.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe had a moral dilemma about whether to report his colleague‚Äôs mistake.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team was in a dilemma after both their star players got injured.‚Äù
‚ÄúChoosing between the two equally appealing vacation spots was a tough dilemma.‚Äù



Synonym
quandary

Vocabulary/dime.title: dime
Vocabulary/dime.content:
dime
Word Type: Noun
Definition
an American or Canadian coin that has the value of ten cents.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHe gave me a dime for the phone call.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe price of the snack was only a dime, so I bought several.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe found a dime on the sidewalk while walking to school.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt have a dime to his name after spending all his money on tickets.‚Äù
‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe this book costs just a dime at the thrift store!‚Äù



Idiom
be a dime a dozen
drop dimes

Word Type: Noun
Definition
A range of different things, such as ideas, opinions, or qualities, that are usually ordered in a particular way.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe museum‚Äôs exhibit covers a wide spectrum of art from ancient to modern.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe political party represents a spectrum of views, from conservative to progressive.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe teacher explained the spectrum of colors visible in a rainbow.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe charity supports a spectrum of causes, from education to healthcare.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe conference covered a broad spectrum of topics related to technology and innovation.‚Äù

Vocabulary/stem.title: stem
Vocabulary/stem.content:
stem
Word Type: Verb & Noun
Definition

To originate or arise from a particular source or cause.
a central part of something from which other parts can develop or grow, or which forms a support.



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe problem stems from a lack of communication between the teams.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis confidence stems from years of experience in the field.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe difficulty stems from outdated technology in the system.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer passion for art stems from childhood experiences with painting.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe tension in the room stems from the ongoing disagreement.‚Äù

Vocabulary/tardiness.title: tardiness
Vocabulary/tardiness.content:
tardiness
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The quality or state of being late or delayed.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHis tardiness to meetings became a problem at work.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe teacher spoke to the student about his tardiness in submitting assignments.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer tardiness at the event was noticed by everyone.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe manager warned the team about the consequences of frequent tardiness.‚Äù
‚ÄúDue to his habitual tardiness, he was given a warning by his employer.‚Äù

Vocabulary/triumph.title: triumph
Vocabulary/triumph.content:
triumph
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A great victory or achievement, especially one that is difficult or hard-earned.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúWinning the gold medal at the Olympics was a tremendous triumph for the athlete.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team‚Äôs triumph over their rivals was celebrated by the entire city.‚Äù
‚ÄúAfter years of struggle, she finally achieved the triumph of publishing her first book.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe company‚Äôs triumph in the market was due to innovative strategies.‚Äù
‚ÄúOvercoming his personal challenges was a true triumph of determination.‚Äù

Vocabulary/truant.title: truant
Vocabulary/truant.content:
truant
Word Type: Noun
Definition
A student who stays away from school without leave or explanation.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe teacher called the parents of the truant student to discuss his absences.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe school is trying to reduce the number of truants by offering more engaging programs.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis frequent absences marked him as a truant, which affected his grades.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe principal met with the truant to discuss the importance of attending school regularly.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe school sends a letter home when a student is marked as a truant too many times.‚Äù

Vocabulary/unambiguous.title: unambiguous
Vocabulary/unambiguous.content:
unambiguous
Definition
Word Type: adjective
expressed in a way that makes it completely clear what is meant:


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The minister promised a clear and unambiguous statement on the future of the coal industry.

Vocabulary/unfiltered.title: unfiltered
Vocabulary/unfiltered.content:
unfiltered
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
Not edited or refined; raw, direct, or without censorship.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúHis unfiltered comments during the meeting made everyone uncomfortable.‚Äù
‚ÄúShe gave an unfiltered opinion about the new project, speaking her mind freely.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe interview was unfiltered, revealing the actor‚Äôs true feelings about the industry.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis unfiltered enthusiasm for the new idea was contagious.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe blog post contained unfiltered insights into the author‚Äôs personal struggles.‚Äù

Vocabulary/unprecedentedly.title: unprecedentedly
Vocabulary/unprecedentedly.content:
unprecedentedly
Word Type: Adverb
Definition
In a way that has never happened or been done before; uniquely or exceptionally.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe company grew unprecedentedly in the last quarter, doubling its profits.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team performed unprecedentedly well, breaking all previous records.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe region experienced unprecedentedly high temperatures this summer.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis success in the competition was unprecedentedly swift and remarkable.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe event was organized unprecedentedly well, exceeding everyone‚Äôs expectations.‚Äù

Vocabulary/vaguely.title: vaguely
Vocabulary/vaguely.content:
vaguely
Word Type: Adverb
Definition
In a way that is unclear, imprecise, or lacking in detail.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe vaguely remembered meeting him at a party years ago.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe instructions were written vaguely, making it hard to follow.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe spoke vaguely about his future plans, not giving much detail.‚Äù
‚ÄúI vaguely recall seeing that movie, but I don‚Äôt remember the plot.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe report vaguely touched on the issue but didn‚Äôt provide any solutions.‚Äù

Vocabulary/validation.title: validation
Vocabulary/validation.content:
validation
Word Type: Noun
Definition
The act of confirming, supporting, or recognizing the truth, accuracy, or worth of something or someone.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúThe scientist‚Äôs research received validation through peer reviews.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer feelings were given validation by her close friends and family.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team‚Äôs hard work gained validation after the successful launch of the product.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe sought validation from his colleagues before making a final decision.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe certificate provided validation of her skills in the field.‚Äù

Vocabulary/wholeheartedness.title: wholeheartedness
Vocabulary/wholeheartedness.content:
wholeheartedness
Word Type: Adjective
Definition
With complete sincerity, enthusiasm, or commitment.


                  
                  Example 
                  
                


‚ÄúShe gave a wholehearted effort to the community project.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe team showed wholehearted support for their coach after the challenging season.‚Äù
‚ÄúHis wholehearted dedication to the cause earned him admiration from everyone.‚Äù
‚ÄúThey accepted the challenge with wholehearted enthusiasm.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer wholehearted belief in the project inspired everyone around her.‚Äù

Vocabulary/wrench.title: wrench
Vocabulary/wrench.content:
wrench
Word Type: Verb & Noun
Definition

to pull and twist something suddenly or violently away from its position.
to suddenly take someone from people they love, causing them great unhappiness.
a tool for holding and turning objects, especially one that can be made larger and smaller to hold different sized objects



                  
                  Example 
                  
                


The photographer tripped over the cord, wrenching a microphone from its stand.
The phone had been wrenched from/off the wall.
The ball was wrenched out of his grasp by another player.
His hands were tied but he managed to wrench himself free.
At the age of eight, she was wrenched from her foster parents and sent to live with another family.

Weekly-Routine.content:

Complete at least all daily quests (3 quests)



Daily quizzes in Anki
Weekly Assignment (from 1 to 3)

Daily study session on Anki
- You will have 2 decks: one made by the teacher, and one you made yourself.
- Each session will have at least 20 words from both deck, concluded only after you are certain **all words are at Easy level.**


 Weekly Assignments

Personalized tests will be given via Canvas
Daily wrap-up on what you‚Äôve learned and make inquiries (at least 2 questions for each lecture)



During Class

Note down new words and grammar structures that the teacher has mentioned.
Spontaneous Knowledge Check on first level recursion of previously encountered words.

Reward & Punishment System

Everybody starts with 0 points each week - no accumulation from prior weeks.
Points can be earned by completing tasks, while failing to meet goals results in point deductions.

Deductions

 Aforementioned weakness/issue: 2 points each

 Make sure you understand Anki philosophy and note down all the new words.

index.title: Introduction
index.content:
Greetings, Family
Our class will begin this week, I hope that we will have a smooth sailing journey together.
A Personal Note
First, this is deeply personal for me, and I trusted you guys to keep this between us, so DO NOT share with anyone, okay? Even though it‚Äôs on public domain :D
Typically, I would jot down these reflections in my journal but for this occasion, to motivate you guys, to hopefully ignite a flame of undying passion for learning, I would like to share a snapshot of my life. First, one of my early mottos:

My thirst for knowledge will never be quenched.
If you don‚Äôt like it, then tough luck, take this as a reading task, and I‚Äôve highlighted the vocabulary that you‚Äôve learned, not the new ones.
So, to mark the commencement of our learning endeavor, here are your first tasks:




                  
                  This week's tasks 
                  
                


  First-level of recursion for new words on this reading task.
 Your comments/remarks (at least 3), send me personally or via group chat, suit you.
 Extra 2 points for those who note grammar structures used as well. An exhaustive one.



‚ö†Ô∏èNote  Minus 1 point for each vocabulary word you miss if asked. Missing means that you haven‚Äôt noted it yet.
Autobiography
People often tell me how ‚Äúa normal person‚Äù would behave differently than I do, so I guess it‚Äôs only reasonable that my school life wasn‚Äôt typical either, lol.
Compared to my peers, I didn‚Äôt study as much, playing most of the time and often doing the bare minimum or finding unconventional shortcuts to keep pace with them. But lucky me, the so-called ‚Äúpeers‚Äù were all geniuses, so I got put in place a lot. Even if I fooled around, the baseline level of effort to keep up helped me pass almost every important test entry.
My life has been the complete opposite and will probably become of this quote:

You either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain.


Without any intervention, wandering with perplexity and curiosity, I turned into a bad, but meticulous kid that no one seemed to notice.


I believe the duality of one‚Äôs nature will always be present, but my poor decisions were taken lightly, or more accurately, went by unawares.
I‚Äôm not proud, but thankfully, I could get back on the right track without much of a fight.

Primary School
This period was what I called ‚ÄúA Dark Era,‚Äù a time filled with confusion and all sorts of emotions with no self-awareness and restraint.

I was a perfect role model student and, better yet, a bully.
Too sharp for my own good, excelling at anything I picked up, so naturally, I got things in my favor.
People‚Äôs attention and praise probably took a heavy toll on me, feeding an ego that I didn‚Äôt know how to process, but that was no excuse. I was led astray, blinded by the rewards and recognition.

Maybe subtle blame for uncontrollable primal instincts‚Äîaggression, violence, and the desperate need for validation.üòå
Let‚Äôs not delve further‚Ä¶
Secondary School
The Muted Aftermath
A got-away-with-it-somehow spoiled brat ended up in the top class of the top secondary school. I came to my senses only much later on, back then I was still feigning ignorance and acting on impulse, as most children would.
Therefore, I got this uncalled-for luxury of going to school by taxi‚Äîyep, a taxi, alongside my neighborhood friends. Truly a story to be bragging about, for bourgeois families.
The academic life went south from here üòÖ as the impetuous desires got the better of me. I skipped classes more than I skipped meals.
I would told the cab driver to stop by the net on the way to school =))) and he would happily do so, since he was paid. Not my kid, not my problem üòÇüòÇ Gotta respect that attitude. Had a lot of fun and a lot of bad grades‚Ä¶ Everything was on a downward spiral, yet funny enough, I never got caught or confronted.
Underappreciated Youth
I formed bonds with most of my closest friends here with the most unfiltered, raw, and rough version of myself. The same goes for them.
These low-maintenance relationships, I believe, will stay unstained, growing stronger yet unaffected by time and distance as it has always been.
We were not only in the best but also the wealthiest class. We could go on weekend trips if any of the generous parents were happy that their kid scored a 10. A local prize would almost guarantee a trip and a national one!? We‚Äôd have back-to-back class holidays! Without spending a dime.
This seemingly chill class turned out to have the highest unprecedented acceptance rate at Lam Son Gifted High School.
I doubt I‚Äôll ever have as many extravagant field trips as I did back then. I got to see so much of Vietnam‚Äôs beauty and historical richness ‚Äî things I had long taken for granted.
But it wasn‚Äôt just the scenes and places I overlooked; it was the people too. I discovered so many new emotions‚Äîones that were pivotal, inevitable, but bitterish‚Äîregret, sorrow, rage, and that heartbroken feeling, or whatever you‚Äôd name it.
Most of these feelings were directed at myself: for the decisions I left unmade, for the precious people I failed to cherish until they quietly walked out of my life forever.
Though painful, these realizations became the compass points guiding my future path and were the turning point for me.
High School
Getting into Lam Son has been my most significant cornerstone, though I didn‚Äôt realize it only until recently.
It wasn‚Äôt the school‚Äôs prestige or education (which, in and of itself, is remarkable) that made the difference‚Äîit was the people here who changed me for the better, forever.
My typical day here would start like this:

I‚Äôd wake up late and rush to school, couldn‚Äôt make it on time, thinking ‚Äúscrew it,‚Äù and go buy breakfast with extra, extra toppings, leisurely enjoying every bite.
I was the class secretary, so it was easy for me to make up a lot of excuses for my 15-to-30-minute tardiness. I did this so frequently that everyone gradually stopped questioning my legitimacy.
Getting away with it almost every time - the pinnacle of gaslighting, huh?

The daily inquiries were rather simple:

What should I eat next?
Where should we hang out after school?
Should we play Werewolves, Ribbit, or Exploding Kittens today?
What rhetorical questions should I ask to make it more impactful during the debate?
Would the Literature teacher let us play board games instead? I probably shouldn‚Äôt be the one bringing it up since she wasn‚Äôt particularly fond of me.
We were in the middle of the game so it would suck if the flow is broken like this.
A board game session typically lasts around 2 hours, but some teachers were flexible enough to let us play through. That‚Äôs why I had the Audacity to consider asking in the first place, though not all were as accommodating.

A Regime That Should Have Been Universal
The educational autonomy level I got was unprecedentedly and inimitably high, along with a hefty budget for students.
We had the freedom to decide how to spend our time, with a monthly salary exceeding a million ‚Äîa huge amount back then,  far more than one student could reasonably spend‚Äî for basically existing.
Students who lived a bit off the beaten track would earn almost twice as much.
Big monetary rewards were given (around 9.000.000‚Ç´ per semester per student) for getting an 8.5 GPA, which was not hard, at all.
The school‚Äôs monthly budget for us was roughly 2 billion VND, as stated by the headmaster.
Amidst all this, the school policy was:

If you wanted to play, play. If you wanted to learn, learn.

By all means, that was the best thing since sliced bread for me.
I got the habit of playing truant since the regulations are so flexible and open. You got to decide what‚Äôs next for you; the temptation level is obviously off the chart for a student, you see.
I could attend only half the lessons (usually two) in the morning, go to the net to play video games, skip the afternoon lecture, and go to the coffee shop with my friends, who would skip as well.
When I first got admitted, I did this a lot, with leading repercussions, of course‚Ä¶ Still, I am lucky enough to have many friends of the same frequency who would do those silly stuff with me and make so much memories, yet I could recount them like the back of my hand.
Each class is financially independent, covering its own bills for electricity, water, and cleaning.
We had a 65‚Äô touchscreen TV, 2 pairs of JBL Speakers in the name of learning listening üòÇ, and lots of mics üé§üé§üé§.
We even bought a pine tree and snow-dry ice dispenser for Christmas.
Every day was either karaoke or movie day with mixed board games and debate contests (a type of roleplay with two opposing teams in parliamentary style, regarding local issues to international dilemmas).
Karaoke was almost an indispensable daily activity, or at least I made it so.
We all shared the same music taste and could jam to the beat forever, do headbang, and even pull off dance covers. The stage was almost always overcrowded.
Despite all the temptations that might have been, the biggest one was not coming to class and missing out on something. I stopped playing truant, more or less.
We traveled a lot, even by plane once, to various provinces in Vietnam. We even got to spend 4 days in Da Nang during the fireworks season; that‚Äôs when I won my 3rd girlfriend, a.k.a current bff, over as well, making it kinda memorable for me. Needless to say, looking back, everything is full of laughter, thrills, and endless singing üéµ üé∂üéµ.
That‚Äôs probably why I love karaoke; it feels like stepping into a bittersweet simulation. Though it‚Äôs never quite the same, the experience always brings back those core memories subconsciously in the best way.
Nostalgia hits hard ü•∫üò¢
Bittersweet Epiphany
From what I can recall, everyone was innocent and carefree in a sense, embracing every passing moment without the slightest care in the world.
The inquiry of what would become of us, or what our hopes and dreams for the future were, never crossed our daily train of thought. Yet I‚Äôm certain they will become the brightest people I know; some already are and are on the brink of refining their identities.
I can still remember that feeling, vaguely - the way dreaming came as naturally as breathing. Just now, I remember someone from those days gave us a name: üå±L√°mer.
For me, high school was when the seed of my fantasies and aspirations was planted, and the mold of my true self was finalized, all stemming from those naive and untroubled experiences. None of what I have achieved, or will achieve, could have happened without those everlasting moments when we could afford to be dreamers. Those fleeting, precious  days shaped our dreams and life trajectories, allowing us to envision a future filled with endless possibilities.
Why do I tell you all this? Why not?
I realized some time ago that the privileges I received should not be taken for granted, as I wouldn‚Äôt trade them for anything.
Now, I see them as something I have to bear on my shoulders, my responsibilities. The spark of life üåüI received is something I long to share, driven by both my sense of obligation and wholeheartedness.
Passing The Torch üî•üî•üî•
Back in the days, my mother brought up the idea that I should take on teaching as a profession. I used to despise that so much, claiming I hated teaching without any real reason‚ÄîI still don‚Äôt know why I said that.
Ironically enough, I started tutoring in 12th grade, have had more than 100 students, and now you guys are my next endeavors.
With hindsight, my mom was quite a prophet, nh·ªâ?
I often tell students about my teachers,  who put me on the right track even when I had strayed far from it‚Äîwhich fact never mattered to them.
I owe a great deal to my life sabers for guiding me during times I needed it most, even without realizing it at the time.
I realized that many kids would have been a lot better off had they met the teachers I once had, those who have the most unconventional methods that I can somewhat fathom now.
My very first students were forced upon me as favors asked by relatives, leaving me with little room for decline. Slowly but surely, teaching had crept up on me and intrigued me as I saw the growth and influence it can have on both parties.
Even though I‚Äôm still learning, I feel like I‚Äôve got a lot to share.

Sharing Is Caring.

Knowledge isn‚Äôt meant to be hoarded like treasure ‚Äî it‚Äôs meant to flow freely, like water. I‚Äôve been fortunate enough to stumble upon this cheat code, and it would be selfish to keep it to myself.
Cheat Code For Life
I believe I possess a wide spectrum of emotions and strong knowledge utilization and I attribute this sort of accomplishment largely to learning languages.
Out of all the skills I‚Äôve learned, learning English has been my ultimate cheat code. I see it as a bridge that connects me to anywhere, any souls across cultures.
I still remember the first time I heard lyrics in a language not my mother tongue, yet they resonated deeply. I had butterflies in my stomach, a sadness so profound that it wrenched my heart. That feeling when words echo straight to the heart, not the brain ‚Äî I felt like discovering an entirely new part of myself.
Then, the new refreshing experiences kept flowing: breaking down in tears watching movies, giggling at random jokes in the comments, discovering beauty hidden between the lines, having words spiraling out of your mind that you didn‚Äôt know were in your possession, and finally seeing the payoff of your efforts.
From the moment I can proudly claim English as my second language, I felt like I got a master key that unlock virtually every door. I‚Äôve walked in the shoes of people from different corners of the world, sharing nothing but a common language, yet it was enough to foster both sympathy and empathy.
Each conversation, each perspective shared, reshapes my understanding of the world. With the advent of the Internet, it‚Äôs like having multiple lives in parallel: experiencing countless joys, struggles, triumphs, and so many unnamed emotions through the eyes of people I‚Äôve never met. Truly a cheat code.
While this might seem commonplace to some, we fell into the category of those who weren‚Äôt entitled to it.
It upsets and frustrates me to see so many may forever remain ignorant of the potential of their growth had they known a few more things.
The foreign viewpoint that reduces a language to merely a subject exists only because they haven‚Äôt witnessed its miracles ‚Äî how it can transform your outlook overnight.
What they dismiss as ‚Äújust English‚Äù is actually a portal to infinite glitches: to friendships that span continents, to knowledge that hasn‚Äôt been translated or better yet translated into this most accessible language, to perspectives that challenge everything you know, to opportunities that others can‚Äôt ever fathom.
They haven‚Äôt yet realized that a language isn‚Äôt just a tool for communication‚Äîit‚Äôs a lens through which to view the world, a key to unlock different versions of yourself simultaneously, to experience the cultural and personality subtle shift as you switch language, and ultimately to a more prosperous eye-opening life.
If you have faith in yourself and trust in me:

Those desired objectives will become your realities.

Ïó¨Í∏∞ÍπåÏßÄ Ïò§Í∏∞Î•º ÏûòÌñàÏñ¥, Îã§Îì§. (Good work for reaching here)
What‚Äôs Next?
Now, you have familiarized yourself with your teacher. Let‚Äôs move on to the class guidelines.

Weekly Routine
